The said Commission shall also make to the City Council reports and
recommendations relative to the sale of securities held in the Sinking Fund and
may recommend to said Council proper investments of the moneys held in the said
Fund, but moneys of such Fund shall be invested only in public improvement,
school, municipal or government bonds.
Section 30. Board of Review; composition; powers and duties.
There shall be a Board of Review of and for the City of Lincoln Park,
consisting of three freeholders who shall be qualified electors and residents
of said City, who shall comprise and constitute a Board of Review of
assessments made for general taxation purposes. Such Board of Review shall meet
at such times, perform such duties and have such powers and responsibilities as
are provided by this Charter and the general laws of the State.
CHAPTER V
City Council
Section 1. Legislative authority.
The legislative authority of the City shall be vested in the Council,
consisting of the Mayor and six Councilmen.
Section 2. Presiding officer; Clerk of Council.
The Mayor shall be the presiding officer of the Council and shall preside at
the meetings thereof. The City Clerk shall be Clerk of the Council.
Section 3. President of Council; designation.
The President of the Council shall be the person receiving the highest number
of votes cast for Councilman at the election at which they are elected.
The President of the Council, in the absence or disability of the Mayor, shall
exercise the powers and duties of Mayor. In the absence of the Mayor and
President, the Council shall appoint one of its members to preside. (Amended
April 3, 1933)
Section 4. Members' qualifications; Council sole judge.
The Council shall be the judge of the qualifications of its own members,
subject only to review of the courts in cases of contest.
Section 5. Council meetings; time; place.
In addition to all other regular meetings in the Charter provided, the Council
shall fix the time and place of its regular meetings each December and shall
hold at least two regular meetings in each month. (Amended November 3, 2009;
May 2, 2023)
Section 6. Special meetings; notice required; procedure.
Special meetings of the Council may be held from time to time, but only when
requested in writing by the Mayor or two Councilmen. Such request shall be
addressed to the City Clerk and shall specify the time and purpose of such
meeting. Immediately upon receipt thereof, the Clerk shall prepare proper
notice of such meeting and serve or cause to be served upon the Mayor and each
Councilman a copy thereof at least six hours before the time for which such
meeting is called, either by delivering such notice to the Mayor and each
Councilman personally, or by leaving it at his place of residence; provided,
however, that if all the members of the Council shall be present at any special
meeting without proper notice, such notice shall be deemed to have been waived.
If all members of the Council shall not be present at such meeting, proof of
the service of notice of such special meeting shall be made by proper affidavit
filed in the office of the City Clerk.
Section 7. Same; notice shall specify business; exception.
No business shall be transacted at any special meeting of the Council unless
the same has been stated in the notice of such meeting; provided, however, that
if all the members of the Council are present at such meeting, then any
business which might lawfully come before a regular meeting of the Council may
be transacted at such special meeting.
Section 8. Meetings open to public; records; public inspection.
All meetings of the Council shall be open to the public. All records of the
Council, as well as all records of the City, shall be kept, and kept only, in
the English language, and all such records shall be open to inspection by the
public.
Section 9. Quorum; adjournment; compelling attendance; authority.
A majority of the members elect of the Council shall constitute a quorum for
the transaction of business, but a less number may adjourn any regular meeting
from time to time and compel the attendance of absent members in such manner as
shall be prescribed by the Council.
Section 10. Rules of proceedings; journal of proceedings required; attestation.
Votes upon all resolutions and ordinances shall be made or rendered by "Yes"
and "No" and entered upon the Journal of Council Proceedings. The Journal shall
be signed by the Clerk and, after reading and approval, attested by the Mayor.
(Amended November 3, 2009)
Section 11. Resolution or ordinance distinguished.
All proceedings of the Council shall be by resolution except where, by the
provisions of this Charter, an ordinance must or may be passed. In the latter
case the Council may pass either an ordinance or resolution.
Section 12. Passing ordinances; penalty; restriction.
Ordinances shall be passed by the Council when this Charter specifically
provides that proceedings of the Council must be taken by ordinance; also when
the Council desires to provide for the commission or prohibition of some thing
and to provide a penalty for the violation of any City law or ordinance shall
not exceed a fine of five hundred dollars or imprisonment in the City prison,
County jail or in any work house in the State authorized by ordinance to
receive prisoners from the City for not more than ninety days, or both, in the
discretion of the court.
Section 13. Ordinances; style; record; publication; effective date;
codification.
The Council shall have full power by ordinance to continue, amend or repeal, in
whole or in part, any existing ordinance. The enacting clause of all ordinances
shall be: "The City of Lincoln Park Ordains." All ordinances, except as herein
otherwise provided, shall require for their passage a majority vote of the
Council elect; and shall take effect immediately upon publication, unless
otherwise provided herein or in the ordinance itself. All ordinances, when
regularly enacted, shall be recorded by the City Clerk in a book called The
Record of Ordinances, and it shall be the duty of the Mayor and Clerk to
authenticate the same by their official signatures upon such record. Within ten
days after the passage of any ordinance, the same shall be recorded by the
Clerk and published in the official newspaper of the City, and the Clerk shall,
immediately after such publication, enter in this record of ordinances, in a
blank space to be left for such purpose under the record of the ordinance, a
certificate under his hand, stating the time and place of such publication.
Such certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the due publication of the
ordinance. In the event that the Council shall codify the ordinances of the
City, such codification may be published by placing not less than one hundred
printed copies thereof in the office of the City Clerk for public inspection
and distribution. No other publication thereof shall be required. A charge for
copies of such codification may be made by the City Clerk upon authorization by
the Council, which charge shall be consistent with the actual cost thereof.
(Amended November 4, 1954)
Section 14. Ordinances; resolutions; regulations; proof.
Whenever it shall be necessary to prove any laws, regulations or ordinances of
this City, or any resolutions adopted by the Council thereof, the same may be
read in all courts and in all proceedings before any tribunal; first, from a
record thereof kept by the Clerk; second, from a copy of the ordinance or of
the record thereof, certified by the Clerk, under the corporate seal of the
City; third, from any compilation of ordinances or any individual ordinance
purporting to have been written or printed by authority of the Council.
Section 15. Ordinances; violations; enforcing penalty; jurisdiction.
Whenever a penalty shall be incurred for the violation of any ordinance, and no
provision shall be made for imprisonment of the offender upon conviction
thereof, or when a corporation shall incur a penalty for the violation of any
such ordinance, the same shall be sued for in the justice court of the City or
in any other court of competent jurisdiction by an action at law.
Section 16. Same; prosecution; time limitation; jurisdiction.
Prosecution for violation of the ordinances shall be commenced within two years
after the commission of the offense, and shall be brought within the City. Any
Municipal Court or Justice of the Peace of the City shall have the authority to
hear, try and determine all causes and suits arising under the ordinances of
the City, and to inflict punishment for violations thereof as provided in the
ordinances.
Section 17. Claims; audit required; regulations.
The Council shall audit and allow all accounts chargeable against the City, but
no account, claim or contract shall be received for audit or allowance unless
it shall be accompanied with a certificate of an officer of the corporation, or
an affidavit of the person rendering it, to the effect that he verily believes
that the services therein charged have been actually performed, or the property
delivered for the City; that the sums charged therefor are reasonable and just;
and that to the best of his knowledge and belief no set-off exists, nor payment
has been made on account thereof, except such as are endorsed or referred to in
such account or claim. Every such account shall exhibit in detail all the items
making up the amount claimed and the true date of each. It shall be a
sufficient defense in any court to any action or proceeding for the collection
of any demand or claim against the City for personal injuries or otherwise that
it has never been presented, certified to or verified as aforesaid to the
Council for allowance; or if such claim is founded on contract that the same
was presented without the certificate or affidavit aforesaid and rejected for
that reason; or that the action or proceeding was brought before the Council
had a reasonable time to investigate and pass upon it.
Section 18. Personal injuries; property damage; claims; notice; contents.
The City shall not be liable in damages sustained by any person in the City,
either to his person or property, by reason of any defective highway, street,
bridge, sidewalk, crosswalk or culvert, or by reason of any obstruction, ice,
snow or other encumbrance upon such street, sidewalk, crosswalk or public
highway, situated in the City, unless such person shall serve or cause to be
served, within sixty days after such injury shall have occurred, a notice, in
writing, upon the Clerk or Deputy Clerk of the City, which notice shall set
forth substantially the time when and the place where such injury took place,
the nature of the defect, the manner in which it occurred, the extent of such
injury as far as the same has become known, the names of the witnesses known at
the time by the claimant and that the person receiving such injury intends to
hold the City liable for such damages as may have been sustained by him, and
shall also, within ninety days next after such injury, present to the City
Clerk his claim, in writing and under oath, setting forth particularly the
nature and extent of such injury and the amount of damages claimed by reason
thereof, which claim shall be presented to the Council.
Section 19. Council proceedings; publication required.
All notices and matters not otherwise required by law to be published in an
official newspaper shall be published electronically on the City's website, on
the City's Government access cable channel, by paper copies posted in at least
4 (four) public buildings and at any other such place as directed by Council.
All notices and matters shall be published and posted within ten days after
their passage.
(Amended April 20, 2020)
Section 20. Official newspaper; designation; publication required; enumeration.
At or prior to its second regular meeting in May, each Council, after
investigating the circulation, rates, quality of printing, deliveries and
responsibility of available newspapers, shall designate some newspaper of
general circulation published in the City, or, in case there be no such
newspaper, then some newspaper published in the County of Wayne, Michigan, and
circulated in the City, as the official newspaper of the City for the next
twelve months. All notices, Council proceedings, ordinances and other records
required by the provisions of this Charter to be published shall be published
in said official newspaper; provided, however, that the Council may order
additional publication of the above notices, Council proceedings, ordinances or
other records in other newspapers, published in said County of Wayne and
circulating in the City.
Section 21. Same; alternate permitted; regulations.
If, at any time, no newspaper has been designated as the official newspaper of
the City, or in case the newspaper as designated ceases regular publication,
the Council in such cases shall designate some newspaper printed, published and
circulated in the City, or if there be none, then some newspaper printed and
published in said Wayne County and circulated in the City, as the official
newspaper of the City for the purpose of publication of some specific notice,
proceedings, etc., required by this Charter to be published, provided the City
shall not be without a designated official newspaper for more than thirty days.
CHAPTER VI
Powers of City and Council
Section 1. Ordinance authorized to exercise powers.
In addition to all other powers in this Charter granted, the City shall have
the general powers and authority granted in this chapter; and the Council shall
pass such ordinances and resolutions as it shall deem expedient in order to
exercise such powers.
Section 2. Council authority; specific matters enumerated.
The Council shall have power to prohibit, prevent and suppress:
      1.   Vice and immorality;
      2.   Houses of ill fame;
      3.   Disorderly and assignation houses;
      4.   The sale or giving away of spirituous, fermented or intoxicating
liquors;
      5.   Saloons;
      6.   Mock auctions and every kind of fraudulent game, device or practice;
      7.   Lotteries, gambling and gambling houses;
      8.   Indecent exposure of the person;
      9.   The show, sale or exhibition for sale of indecent or obscene
pictures, drawings, engravings, paintings, books and pamphlets;
      10.   Indecent or obscene shows and exhibitions;
      11.   Wanton destruction of property;
      12.   Riots;
      13.   Disorderly persons and disorderly assemblages of persons;
      14.   Disturbance of any religious meeting, congregation, society or
other public meeting assembled for any lawful purpose;
      15.   Wearing of masks or covering which conceal part or all of the
wearer's face while assembling, marching or parading on any street, highway or
public place, except masquerade parties or amusement or public parades;
      16.   Use of a red flag, except for railway and transportation purposes,
and except as a sign of danger;
      17.   Nuisances;
      18.   Injury or annoyance from anything dangerous, offensive or
unhealthy; and
      19.   Disorderly persons, prostitutes and any person owning, operating,
maintaining or doing any of the things enumerated above.
The Council shall have power to provide for the arrest and punishment of
vagrants, truants, beggars, drunkards and persons found drunk in any of the
public streets or places of the City.
Section 3. Same; enumeration of powers continued.
The Council shall have power to prohibit, to provide, to regulate and to
license, as the case may be:
      1.   Transient traders;
      2.   Auctioneers;
      3.   Sale at auction of live or domestic animals in the streets, alleys
and public places of the City;
      4.   Auctions and sale at auction, except sales at auction made pursuant
to some order of court or public law;
      5.   Peddlers, hawkers, pawnbrokers;
      6.   Wharf boats, tugs, ferries and other boats within the jurisdiction
of the City, and the charges for transportation of persons and property
thereon;
      7.   The use of aeroplanes in and above the City;
      8.   All vehicles of every kind used for the transportation of persons or
property for hire, and their stands on the streets, alleys and public places in
the City and at boat landings, steam and electric railway stations, and other
places;
      9.   Solicitors of passengers or baggage to or from any hotel, public
house, boat or railway station or place where they may be admitted to solicit
or receive patronage;
      10.   Draymen, car men, truckmen, porters, runners and drivers of
vehicles for hire, and the amounts and rates of their compensation;
      11.   Hotels;
      12.   Restaurants;
      13.   Eating houses;
      14.   Theaters and other places of public entertainment;
      15.   The use, control and regulation of streams, water and watercourses
within its boundaries, but not so as to conflict with the laws or actions
thereunder where a navigable stream is bridged or dammed;
      16.   The depositing in such streams, waters and watercourses of
driftwood, filth or other noxious matter tending to render the waters impure,
unwholesome and offensive;
      17.   Noxious and unsanitary buildings of all kinds, sewers and other
offensive, nauseous or unwholesome places;
      18.   Construction, repair and removal of all buildings, cellars,
cisterns, slips, private drains, sinks, cesspools and privies;
      19.   Partition fences;
      20.   Signs, billboards and advertising devices;
      21.   Awnings;
      22.   Dogs and other domestic animals;
      23.   Pounds;
      24.   The use of the surface of the City streets, alleys and public
grounds, and of the space above and beneath them;
      25.   Vehicular and foot traffic;
      26.   The keeping, selling and using of dynamite, gun powder, fire
crackers, fireworks and other explosive or combustible materials;
      27.   The exhibition of fireworks;
      28.   Firearms;
      29.   The making or lighting of fires in streets, alleys and other open
places in the City;
      30.   The inspection, weighing and measuring of meats, provisions and
other articles of merchandise;
      31.   The inspection and sealing of weights and measures;
      32.   The use of proper weights and measures by vendors;
      33.   The protection and care of paupers and the bringing to the City
from any other place of any pauper or other person likely to become a charge
upon the City;
      34.   Taking a census of the inhabitants;
      35.   Numbering of buildings upon the streets and alleys of the City;
      36.   All matters relating to the peace, safety, good order, good health
and good government of the City, and the general welfare of the inhabitants
thereof; and
      37.   Penalties for the violation of all ordinances.
Section 4. Licenses; terms; conditions; etc.; ordinance required.
The Council shall by ordinance prescribe the terms and conditions upon which
licenses may be  granted, and may require and exact payment of such reasonable
sums for any licenses as it may deem proper. The persons receiving the license
shall, before the issuing thereof, execute a bond to the City, when required by
any ordinance, in such sum and with such sureties as prescribed by such
ordinance, conditioned for the faithful observance of the Charter of the City
and the ordinance under which the license is granted, and otherwise conditioned
as any such ordinance may prescribe. Such license shall be revocable by the
Council at pleasure; and when any license shall be revoked for noncompliance
with the terms and conditions upon which it was granted, the person holding
such license shall, in addition to other penalties imposed, forfeit all payment
made for such license.
Section 5. Licenses; expiration date; transferability; proceeds; fines;
penalties.
No license shall be granted for any term beyond the first Tuesday of May next
thereafter, nor shall any license be transferable. The Council may provide for
the punishment, by fine or imprisonment, or both, of any person who, without
license, shall exercise any occupation or trade or do anything for or in
respect to which any license is required. All license moneys shall be paid into
the City treasury to the credit of the Contingent Fund.
Section 6. Police force personnel.
The Council shall provide for and establish a police force, and shall provide
for the appointment of such number of policemen as it shall deem necessary to
the good government of the City and for the protection of the persons and
property of the inhabitants thereof. The Council may authorize the Mayor, in
cases of emergency and danger, temporarily to appoint such additional policemen
as, in his judgment, the occasion may require. It shall make all necessary
rules for the government of the police and shall prescribe their powers and
duties. When any person has committed or is suspected of having committed any
crime within the City, the police officers of the City shall have the same
rights to pursue, arrest and detain such person without the City limits as the
Sheriff of the County.
Section 7. Public health; preservation; protection.
The Council may enact all such ordinances or resolutions as it may deem
necessary for the preservation and protection of the health of the inhabitants
of the City, to prevent the introduction of malignant, infectious or contagious
diseases into the City and to regulate the same; and for the removal of persons
having such diseases, or who, from exposure thereto or otherwise, may be
suspected or may be liable to communicate the same, to a hospital or place of
treatment within the City, or to some hospital or place of treatment without
the City, as the Council may prescribe or the public safety may require.
Section 7a. Buildings and structures; water and sewer system; connection
required.
No building or structure may hereafter be erected, altered or remodeled which
is to be used for human habitation use or occupancy unless adequate provision
has been made for connecting to the City of Lincoln Park sewer and water
system, and no building permit shall be issued unless the plans for the
proposed structure or alteration indicate such connections, provided that no
certificate of occupancy shall be issued permitting the use or occupancy of any
such building or structure unless and until connection to the public sewer and
water system has been made and such services shall be in operation. (Amended
November 7, 1950)
Section 8. Fire protection.
The Council shall have power to enact such ordinances and resolutions and
establish and enforce such regulations as it shall deem necessary to guard
against the occurrence of fire and to protect the property and persons of the
inhabitants against damage and accident resulting therefrom; and for this
purpose to establish and maintain a Fire Department, to provide for the
appointment of all necessary firemen and other employees and to make and
establish rules for the government of the Department, the employees thereof and
for the care and management of the engine houses, apparatus, property and
buildings pertaining to the Department.
Section 9. Commanding aid at fires; Fire Department authority.
The head of the Fire Department or any fireman in command at a fire may command
any person present to aid in the extinguishment of such fire and to assist in
the protection of property thereat. The Council, by ordinance, shall provide
for the punishment of any person failing to obey such command.
Section 10. Fire districts.
The Council may prescribe by ordinance from time to time limits or districts in
the City within which limits or districts wooden buildings and structures shall
not be erected, placed or enlarged, and to direct the manner of constructing
buildings within such limits or districts with respect to protection against
fire and to the material of which the walls, floors, partitions and roofs shall
be constructed.
Section 11. Zoning.
The Council may also prohibit, within such limits or districts as it deems
expedient, the operation of shops, the prosecution of any trade or business,
the keeping of lumber yards and the storing of lumber, wood or other easily
inflammable materials in open places, when, in the opinion of the Council, the
danger from fire is thereby increased. It may regulate the storing of
gunpowder, oils and other combustible and explosive substances, the use of
lights in buildings and generally may pass and enforce such ordinances and
regulations as it may deem necessary for the prevention and suppression of
fires.
Section 12. Fires; razing buildings; authority; damages; payment;
determination.
The head of the Fire Department or any fireman in command at any fire, with the
concurrence of the Mayor, or any two Councilmen, may cause any building to be
pulled down or destroyed when deemed necessary to arrest the progress of the
fire. When any building is so pulled down or destroyed, any person having an
interest in such building may present his claim for damages to the Council, and
it shall thereupon be the duty of the Council to pay such claimant such damages
as may be just under all of the circumstances, taking into consideration
whether or not such loss would probably have occurred to such building if it
had not been pulled down or destroyed, and whether or not the building was
insured. If the Council and such claimant shall not be able to agree upon the
amount of damages to be paid such claimant, then the amount of such damages
shall be ascertained by the appraisal of a jury, to be selected in the same
manner as in the case of a jury to appraise damages for taking private property
for public use. Such jury may visit the premises and may hear all the proofs in
the case, and shall allow such claimant such amount of damages as it may deem
proper under all the circumstances as above stated. If such jury shall not be
able to agree, a new jury shall be empaneled as above provided, until a jury
has been obtained that shall agree, and the Council shall pay such claimant the
amount of damages fixed by such jury. The verdict of such jury shall be final
and conclusive and there shall be no appeal therefrom either by the City or by
the claimant.
Section 13. Fire hazards; nuisance declared; abatement.
Every building or structure which may be erected, placed, enlarged or kept in
violation of any ordinance or resolution lawfully made for the prevention of
fires is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be abated or removed in the
discretion of the Council.
Section 14. Building sidewalks; regulations; ordinance required; violations;
penalty.
Sidewalks, except crosswalks, shall be built by the owners of lands within the
City in the manner and within the time prescribed by ordinance; provided that
in case of the failure of any such owner to comply with the provisions of such
ordinance the City may build or cause to be built such sidewalk and assess
against such owner the cost thereof, together with an additional ten percent of
such cost as a penalty for the violation of such ordinance.
Section 15. City utilities; service beyond City boundaries.
The Council may sell to persons outside the City limits the product of any
public utility owned by the City; provided, however, that the amount of the
product so sold shall not exceed twenty-five percent of the amount of such
product furnished within the City limits.
Section 16. Approval of plats; requisites.
No lands or premises shall hereafter be laid out, divided and platted into
lots, streets and alleys within said City, except by permission and approval of
the Council by resolution passed for that purpose; nor until the proprietor
shall file with the City Clerk a correct survey, plan and map of such grounds
and the subdivision thereof, platted and subdivided as approved by the Council,
and made to its satisfaction; showing also the relative position and location
of such lots, streets and alleys with respect to the adjacent lots and streets
of the City. As a condition of approving such plat, the Council may require
that all streets shown on said plat shall be graded and cinderized or otherwise
improved; all ditches, drains and culverts, necessary to make such streets
usable constructed and cement sidewalks constructed in the proper place and in
accordance with the sidewalk specifications of the City, along the street lines
of all lots shown on such plat abutting upon any street in such subdivision.
The Council may, in its discretion, accept a bond in amount and with sureties
satisfactory to the Council, conditioned upon the installation of all the above
mentioned improvements within a time determined by the Council and limited in
such bond, and in such case shall accept such plat and authorize the Clerk to
certify upon such plats its acceptance by the Council.
Section 17. Public ways; sewers; supervision and control.
Subject to existing legal grants, and the provisions of the general laws of
this State, the Council shall have the supervision and control of all public
highways, bridges, streets, avenues, alleys and public grounds within the City,
shall have power to lay out, establish, open, make, widen, extend, straighten,
alter, close, vacate or abolish any highway, street, lane, alley, sewer, drain,
watercourse, bridge or culvert in the City, or change the name or grade of any
street and if, in doing so, it shall be necessary to take or use private
property, the same may be taken and paid for in the manner provided in this
Charter; provided, however, that whenever the Council shall deem it advisable
to vacate, discontinue or abolish any highway, street, lane or alley, or any
part thereof, or change the grade or name thereof, they shall by resolution so
declare, and in the same resolution shall appoint a time, not less than four
weeks thereafter, when they will meet and hear objections thereto; notice of
such meeting with a copy of said resolution shall be given in such manner as
the Council by ordinance or resolution shall prescribe. Objections in writing
may be filed with the City Clerk, and if any shall be filed, the street, alley
or public ground or any part thereof shall not be vacated, discontinued or
abolished or the grade or name thereof changed, except by the concurring vote
of three-fifths of the Council elect. And the City shall have power to acquire,
by construction or otherwise, a system of trunk sewers and may extend such
trunk sewers beyond the territory of the City whenever the Council shall deem
it necessary or expedient so to do in order to secure an outlet, and if the
Council shall deem it for the best interests of the City so to do, permanent
flowage rights in trunk sewers owned by neighboring municipalities may be
acquired by purchase or contract and such rights shall be considered a part of
the sewer system of the City and the cost of acquiring such permanent flowage
rights shall be a legal and proper expenditure of City funds.
Section 18. Public ways; use for utilities; compensation.
The Council shall have full power to provide for the use, upon the payment of
reasonable compensation by others than the owner, of property located in
streets, alleys and public places and used in the operation of public
utilities.
Section 19. Sale of public property; limitation.
   Subject to the limitations contained in Section 20 following, the City shall
have power, upon proper resolution of the Council, to sell any of its real
property, provided that the value of any real property to be sold does not
exceed one dollar per capita according to the last preceding census. (Amended
November 8, 2004)
   In disposing of its personal property, the Mayor and City Council shall have
the authority to sell, lease or trade such personal property on terms deemed
appropriate to a majority thereof. Said personal property shall be disposed of
in such a way as to ensure the City receives at least the fair market value of
said property, and such disposal shall be made by competitive bid or auction at
a public hearing.
(Amended November 5, 1991)
Section 20. Same; requisites.
The Council may sell any real property of the City of a value in excess of one
dollar per capita according to the last census; may sell any park, cemetery or
any real estate and in carrying on a public utility, or any part thereof, or
any property bordering on a water front; or may vacate any street or public
place leading to a water front; provided, however, that any such proposition
shall have first received the affirmative vote of three-fifths of the qualified
electors of the City voting thereon at an election called in accordance with
the provisions of Chapter II of this Charter relating to elections. (Amended
November 5, 1991; Amended November 8, 2004)
Section 21. Authority to receive gifts, bequests and donations.
The City may receive bequests, gifts and donations of all kinds of property in
fee simple or in trust for public charitable or other purposes; and to do all
things and acts necessary to carry out the purposes of such bequests, gifts and
donations, with power to manage, sell, lease or otherwise handle or dispose of
the same, in accordance with the terms of the bequest, gift or donation.
Section 22. Acquisition of property.
The Council shall have power to acquire by purchase, lease, condemnation,
construction or otherwise, and to establish, hold, equip, maintain, conduct,
manage and operate, libraries, reading rooms, play grounds, public grounds,
parks, boulevards, baths, public toilet and comfort stations, markets, market
houses, waterworks, municipal lodging houses, infirmaries, hospitals, free
employment bureaus, jails, police stations, fire houses, works or plants for
the preparation, manufacture, handling or transportation of materials required
in the construction, completion, maintenance or repair of any public building
work, improvement or utility, and any and all buildings, establishments,
institutions and places which are necessary or convenient for the transaction
of public business or for promoting the health, morals or welfare of the
inhabitants of the City, or for their regulation or benefit.
Section 23. Acquisition of real estate.
The Council shall have power to acquire, own, erect, maintain, manage and
control real estate, buildings, institutions, and works without the corporate
limits of the City, except where prohibited by this Charter or the general laws
of this State, and to enforce beyond the corporate limits of the City and over
such lands, buildings, institutions and property all ordinances and police
regulations as may be necessary for the care, protection, control and
management thereof in the same manner and to the same extent as if they were
located within the City.
Section 24. Markets.
The Council shall have power to establish and regulate markets and market
places for the sale of meats, fish, vegetables and other provisions and
articles necessary for the sustenance and convenience of the inhabitants.
Section 25. Partition fences.
The Council shall have power to enact all such ordinances and laws as it may
deem proper relative to the building, rebuilding, maintaining and repairing of
partition fences by the owners and occupants of adjoining lots, enclosures and
parcels of land in the City; and relative to the assigning to the owners or
occupants of such adjoining pieces of land the portion of such partition fences
to be maintained by them respectively; and may provide for the recording of
such assignments and division when made; and may provide for the recovery of
damages from any owner or occupant who shall fail to comply with the provisions
and requirements of any ordinance relative to such partition fences. The
Council may appoint fence viewers and prescribe their duties and mode of
proceeding in all cases relating to partition fences in the City.
Section 26. Impounding vehicles, animals, etc.  
The Council shall have power to provide, maintain and regulate one or more
pounds and may authorize the impounding of all vehicles, beasts and fowls found
in the street or otherwise at large, contrary to any ordinance of the City; to
prescribe the fees for impounding, and the amount or rate of expense for
keeping and the charge to be paid by the owner or keeper of the vehicles,
beasts or fowls impounded; to authorize the sale of the vehicles, beasts or
fowls for the payment of such fees, expenses and charges, and for penalties
incurred, and may impose penalties for rescuing any beast or fowl impounded.
The Chief of Police shall be pound master, ex officio, without additional
compensation or fees.
Section 27. Nuisance abatement.
The Council shall have power to prevent, remove and abate all nuisances
dangerous to life or health within the City and may require any person,
corporation or company causing such nuisance, and the owner or occupant of any
lot or premises upon or in which any such nuisance or cause of diseases may be
found, to remove or abate the same upon such notice and within such time and in
such manner as the Council may be ordinance or resolution direct.
Section 28. Buildings and zoning.
The Council shall have power to regulate and limit the height and bulk of
buildings hereafter erected, and regulate and determine the area of yards,
courts and other open spaces, and for such purposes divide the City into
districts of such number, shape and area as may be deemed best suited to carry
out the purposes of this section. Such regulations shall be uniform for each
class of buildings throughout each district, but the regulations in one
district may differ from those in other districts. Such regulations shall be
made in accordance with a plan designed to lessen congestion on the public
streets and to promote public health, safety and general welfare, and shall be
made with reasonable consideration, among other things, to the character of the
district, its peculiar suitability for particular uses, the conservation of
property values and the general trend and character of building and population
development.
Section 29. Railways.
Subject to the provisions of existing contracts between steam and electric
railways and the Village of Lincoln Park, the County of Wayne or the State of
Michigan, and subject to the general laws of the State applicable thereto, the
Council shall have full power over all railways passing or desiring to pass
through the City, and by ordinance may provide the terms and conditions under
which such railways may run, operate and maintain their trains, tracks, etc.,
in the City.
Section 30. Public utility franchises.
The Council shall have full power in itself to grant any public utility
franchise; provided such franchise is revocable at the will of the Council. It
may also grant any public utility franchise and also franchise for the use or
occupancy of any street or alley for any lawful purpose, any such franchise to
run for a definite period of time not to exceed thirty years; provided,
however, that no such franchise shall be granted by the Council until the
proposition to grant such franchise shall have first been submitted to the
qualified electors of the City at an election and shall have received the
affirmative vote of three-fifths of the qualified electors voting thereon. No
franchise grant or license shall be submitted under the provisions of this
Charter to the electors at a special election, unless the expense of holding
the election, as determined by the Council, shall be paid in advance by the
grantee in said franchise grant or license, to the City Treasurer.
Section 31. Employment of experts.
Whenever it shall deem the same advisable, the Council shall have full power in
itself, subject to the provisions of this Charter, to employ architects,
engineers, doctors, attorneys and other persons possessing expert knowledge and
ability, to aid in the acquiring, purchasing, constructing, altering,
extending, regulating and supervising any public improvement or department of
the City requiring such service. The cost of expert services rendered under the
provisions of this section in the preparation of necessary estimates of cost,
diagrams, plans and maps of any contemplated public improvement or upon the
actual construction or installment of such public improvement shall be
considered part of the cost thereof to be paid out of moneys provided for such
public improvement; otherwise the expense of such expert services shall be paid
out of the general funds of the City.
Section 32. Municipal powers; public utilities and improvements.
The Council shall have full power to provide for the establishment,
construction, operation, maintenance, regulation and supervision of all public
utilities and other public improvements, whether the same be expressly
enumerated in this Charter or not; for the enforcement of all such local,
police, sanitary, health and other regulations as are not in conflict with the
general laws of this State; for exercising all Municipal powers in the
management of Municipal property and in the administration of the Municipal
government, whether such powers be herein expressly enumerated or not; for any
act to advance the interest, the good government and prosperity of the City and
its inhabitants; and shall further have authority to enact all ordinances and
to make all regulations consistent with this Charter and the laws and
Constitution of this State as they may deem necessary for the safety, order and
good government of the City and the general welfare of the inhabitants thereof.
Section 33. Authority to borrow; State law.
Subject to limitations in this Charter or in the Constitution or general laws
of the State contained, the City may borrow money for any public purpose in
this Charter specifically permitted, or not specifically forbidden, and may
issue the bond or bonds of the City for the repayment thereof, together with
any and all interest, not exceeding a legal rate, which may accrue thereon.
Section 34. Specific grants of authority not limited; exception.
The granting to the City or Council of any specific power in this Charter shall
not be construed as limiting any general grant of powers unless the intention
to so limit is clearly indicated.
Section 35. Authority granted by State law incorporated by reference.
All power now legally possessed by cities organized and existing under the
provisions of Act No. 279 of the Public Acts of Michigan for the year 1909, as
amended (commonly known as the Home Rule Act for Cities), and all Municipal
powers not now possessed by so-called home rule cities in Michigan, but which
may hereafter be granted by constitutional or legislative enactment, whether by
amendments to the so-called Home Rule Act for Cities or by general law, are
hereby reserved to the City of Lincoln Park, and, unless restricted by the
self-imposed limitations in this Charter contained, may be exercised, enjoyed
and enforced as fully as if the same were specifically adopted as provisions
hereof.
CHAPTER VII
Finance and Taxation
Section 1. Fiscal year.
The fiscal year of the City shall begin on the first day of July and end at
midnight of the 30th day of June of the succeeding year.
Section 2. Power to tax.
The Council of the City of Lincoln Park shall have authority, within the
limitations herein prescribed, to raise annually, by general tax upon the real
and personal property liable to taxation in said City, such sums of money as
they shall deem necessary to defray the expenses and pay the liabilities of
said City and to carry into effect the powers of this Charter granted.
Section 3. Annual appropriation bill.
On or before the first Monday in May of each year, every elective officer of
the City and every officer and administrative board appointed by the Council
shall prepare and file with the Controller estimates, in detail, of the expense
of operation of the various departments under their control for the period of
one year next succeeding the first day of July following. Such estimates shall
clearly set forth the different items of estimated expense, such as salaries,
compensation, new apparatus, appliances and supplies, up-keep, repairs, etc.
Such estimates shall be tabulated by the Controller and transmitted to the
Council. Such estimates shall be accompanied by statistics of the amount
appropriated for the current year, balance on hand or overdraft or deficiency
by reason of uncollected taxes or otherwise. The Council shall, on or before
the Tuesday following the second Monday in June, by resolution appearing upon
the minutes, designate the sums allowed and appropriated and to be raised by
taxation for the various funds. The Controller shall prepare estimates for the
general expense of the City not included in the estimates hereinbefore provided
for.
Section 4. Taxes; revenues divided into enumerated funds.
All revenues raised by general tax upon all the property in the City, or by
loan to be repaid by such tax, shall be divided into so many of the following
funds as are necessary:
      First: General Fund--to defray the general expenses and liabilities of
the corporation and to carry into effect the powers in this Charter granted,
except as in this section set forth.
      Second: Sinking Fund--irrevocably pledged to pay the bonded debt of the
City.
      Third: Such other funds as the Council may from time to time constitute.
Section 5. Same; restriction.
   The aggregate amount which the Council may raise by general tax upon the
taxable real and personal property in the City, for any and all purposes of the
corporation, shall not, except as herein otherwise provided, exceed in any one
year two percent of the assessed value of such property.
   Authorize a Renewal of the Millage not to exceed 3.4591 mills for three (3)
years, 2023 through 2026, solely for police and fire purposes.
(Adopted 1-6-07; Amended: 11-2-10 & 11-5-13; Amended: 8-2-16; Amended: 4-6-20;
6-20-22)
   This amendment will authorize a tax of not to exceed 0.35 mill for three
years, 2011 through 2013, solely for library purposes. Approval would increase
the tax levy by 0.35 mill as new additional millage in excess of the limitation
imposed by law, restoring a portion of the Charter millage authorization
previously approved by the electors, since reduced by the Headlee amendment. It
is estimated that if levied, 0.35 mill would raise approximately $280,000 when
first levied in 2008.
(Amended November 6, 2007; November 2, 2010)
Section 6. Assessment roll; preparation; procedure.
The Assessor of the City shall, on or before the first Monday in June in each
year, make an assessment roll containing a description of all the real property
and the aggregate amount of all personal property liable under the laws of the
State to taxation in the City, and the name of the owner, agent or person
liable to pay taxes thereon, if known, and shall set down in such roll the
valuation of such property, as its true cash value, placing the value of the
real and personal property in separate columns and in so doing, unless
otherwise provided in this Charter, he shall conform to and be governed by the
provisions of law governing assessing officers performing like services in the
assessment of property for State and County taxes.
Section 7. Board of Review; powers and duties.
The Board of Review shall meet at the Council Chambers in the City Hall on the
third Tuesday in April and fourth Monday and Tuesday of April each year for the
purpose of reviewing and correcting such assessments. The Board of Review shall
have the same powers and perform like duties in all respects as are by general
tax law conferred upon and required of board of review in townships, in
reviewing assessments in townships for State and County taxes. They shall hear
the complaints of all persons considering themselves aggrieved by such
assessments, and if it shall appear that any person has been wrongfully
assessed or omitted from the roll, the Board shall correct the roll in such
manner as they shall deem just. (Amended April 4, 1927)
Section 8. Same; record of changes required.
Said Board of Review shall make a record of all changes made in the roll, which
record shall be signed by them and deposited with the Clerk.
Section 9. Same; endorsement of assessment roll.
Immediately after the review of the assessment roll as aforesaid, a majority of
the Board of Review shall endorse the roll as provided in the general tax law.
The omission of such endorsement shall not effect the validity of such roll.
Upon the completion of said roll and its endorsement in the manner aforesaid,
the same shall be conclusively presumed by all courts and tribunals to be
valid, and shall not be set aside except for such causes as are provided in the
general tax laws of the State for the setting aside of assessment rolls for
State, County and school purposes.
Section 10. Assessment roll; State, County, School and City taxes; State law;
collection.
The assessment roll herein provided for shall be the assessment roll for State,
County, School and City taxes. After the Board of Review shall have approved
such assessment roll, the Assessor shall, within the proper time, spread
thereon the amount of the State and County taxes and also School taxes, if
raised at the same time as the State and County taxes, in the manner and form
provided therefor by the general tax law of the State, or any special or local
act relating thereto, and such taxes shall become a debt and a lien, and be
levied, collected, accounted for and returned, and the property assessed
therefor, sold, held, redeemed and conveyed at the time and in the manner and
form provided for in the general tax law of the State, except as herein
otherwise provided. The Assessor shall prepare a copy of said assessment roll,
with taxes assessed as herein provided, which roll shall be known as the
"General Tax Roll," and shall annex thereto such warrant signed by him, as is
provided for by the general tax laws of the State. Said general tax roll shall
thereupon be delivered to the City Treasurer, who shall collect said taxes in
the manner provided by the general laws of the State.
Section 11. School taxes; City officers; powers and duties.
In all proceedings in relation to the assessment, spreading and collection of
taxes for school purposes, and in relation to the receipt and disbursement of
all moneys belonging to the school district, the City Assessor, City Clerk and
City Treasurer shall have like powers and duties as are prescribed by the laws
of this State for supervisors of townships, township clerks and township
treasurers, respectively.
Section 12. General tax; amount; certification by Clerk; apportionment by
Treasurer.
The Clerk, after the Council has determined the several amounts which they
require to be raised by general tax for the several funds of the City, and the
aggregate thereof, shall certify the same to the City Treasurer. When such
general taxes shall be received by the Treasurer, they shall be apportioned to
the several funds of the City pro rata according to the several amounts of said
funds so certified.
Section 13. Same; special assessments; amounts; certification by Clerk to
Assessor.
The Clerk shall certify to the Assessor the total amounts which the Council
determines shall be raised by general tax; and all amounts of special
assessments which the Council requires to be reassessed upon any lands or
premises or against any person, with a particular description of the lands upon
each parcel of land, and the name or names, so far as known, of the persons
chargeable with such tax.
Section 14. City tax roll; preparation; contents.
After the endorsement of the assessment roll by the Board of Review, the
Assessor shall prepare a copy thereof to be known as the City tax roll, and
upon receiving the said certificates of the several amounts to be raised, as
provided in the preceding section, the Assessor shall proceed to estimate,
apportion and set down in columns opposite to the several valuations of real
and personal property on said tax roll, in proportion to the individual and
particular estimates and valuations, the respective sums in dollars and cents,
apportionable to each; placing the general taxes in one column; all special
assessment taxes in a second column; the school taxes, if raised at the same
time, in a third column; and the total of all taxes assessed to each valuation
shall be carried into the last column of such roll.
Section 15. Same; certification by Assessor; due date; nonpayment; penalty;
remedies.
After extending the taxes as aforesaid, the Assessor shall certify under his
hand said tax roll, and the Mayor of the City shall annex his warrant thereto,
directing and requiring the Treasurer to collect from the several persons named
in said roll the several sums mentioned therein opposite to their respective
names as a tax or assessment, and authorizing him, in case any person named
therein shall neglect or refuse to pay such sums, to levy the same by distress
and sale of his, her or their goods and chattels, together with the costs and
charges of such distressor sale. Such warrant shall further direct that all
taxes paid on or before the 20th day of August shall be collected without
additional charge, and that there shall be added to all taxes paid after said
20th day of August one percent of each and every month or fraction thereof that
the same remains unpaid. Provided, however, that when any person liable for the
City tax on any property shall pay one-third thereof on or before the 20th day
of August in the year in which said tax is assessed, and shall at the time of
payment give notice to the City Treasurer, that he will pay the second one-
third on or before October 15 of said year, and the remaining one-third on or
before February 28 of following year, said person shall have the right so to do
without any further addition, penalty or interest. The City Treasurer shall
give to each taxpayer so paying his taxes an appropriate receipt showing that
one-third of the tax is paid and that notice has been received that the other
two-thirds will be paid on or before dates above mentioned, and shall make
entry of such payment and notice on the proper tax roll. Said City tax roll and
annexed warrant, together with a true copy thereof, shall be delivered by the
Assessor to the Treasurer on or before the first day of July of the year when
made.
(Amended April 3, 1933; November 8, 1983; November 5, 1991)
Section 16. Same; delivery to Treasurer; Treasurer's duties.
Upon receiving the tax roll, with the warrant thereto annexed, the Treasurer
shall mail to all persons whose names appear upon said roll statements of the
taxes levied against them respectively as shown upon said roll and on and after
the 15th day of July of that year shall proceed to collect the taxes levied
therein according to the direction of said warrant and the provisions of this
Charter. The failure to mail or receive a tax statement shall not affect the
validity of the tax and shall not be an excuse for the nonpayment of such tax
within the time or times herein limited for payment.
Section 17. Unpaid taxes; return to County Treasurer required.
If the Treasurer has been unable to collect any of the taxes on said tax roll
on real property before the first day of March following the date when said
roll was received by him, then it shall be his duty to return all such unpaid
taxes on real property to the County Treasurer in the same manner and with like
effect as returns by township treasurers. Such return shall include all the
additional charges hereinbefore provided, which charges shall in such return be
added to the amount assessed in said roll against each description. The taxes
thus returned shall be collected in the same manner as other taxes returned to
such County Treasurer are collected under the provisions of the general tax
laws of the State, and the same rate of interest and all charges shall be
collected thereon, and all taxes upon lands so returned as delinquent shall be
and remain a lien thereon until paid.
Section 18. Same; sale of lands; proceeds; State law.
Moneys received from the sale of lands for delinquent City taxes shall be paid
over to the City Treasurer. All of the provisions of the general tax laws
relative to the sale and redemption of lands returned for delinquent taxes
shall apply to the sale and redemption of lands returned for delinquent taxes
assessed under the provisions of this Charter.
Section 19. Same; goods and chattels; distress sale.
In case any person shall neglect or refuse to pay any tax imposed upon any real
or personal property belonging to him, as aforesaid, the Treasurer shall levy
the same by distress and sale of the goods and chattels of the said person
liable to pay the same, wherever such goods and chattels may be found, either
in said City or elsewhere in the County of Wayne, or in an adjoining county,
first giving public notice of such sale in the manner and for the time required
by law in case of such sales made by township treasurers, and for such purpose
and for the collection of the taxes aforesaid, the Treasurer may bring suit
therefor in the name of the City, and shall have all the powers and perform the
like duties, so far as applicable, as are conferred upon or required of
township treasurers in the collection of taxes levied in townships.
Section 20. Same; suit to enforce payment; State law.
Whenever the Treasurer shall be unable to collect any tax assessed upon
personal property in the City, it shall be lawful for the Treasurer of the City
to bring suit, in the name of the City, for the recovery thereof, against the
person or persons against whom the tax was assessed, before any court of
competent jurisdiction, and to take and use all lawful means for the collection
of debts to enforce the payment of such tax; and in such cases all of the
provisions of law applicable to suits and evidence therein brought by township
treasurers in the name of their township for such purpose shall apply.
Section 21. Property subject to taxation; State law.
The real and personal property subject to taxation for the Municipal purposes
of this City shall be the same as for State, County and School purposes under
the general law of the State.
Section 22. Taxes; debt; lien; continuance.
The City taxes when assessed shall become at once a debt to the City from the
persons to whom they are assessed, and the amounts assessed on any interest in
real property shall on the first day of July become a lien upon such real
property and the lien for such amounts, and for all interest and charges, shall
continue until payment thereof. And all personal taxes shall also be a lien on
all personal property of such persons so assessed, from and after the first day
of July in each year, and shall take precedence of any sale, assignment or
chattel mortgage, levy or other lien on such personal property, executed or
made after the said first day of July, except where such property is actually
sold in the regular course of trade.
Section 23. Authority to borrow in anticipation of taxes.
The Council may borrow in anticipation of the collection of taxes for the same
or next succeeding fiscal year, such sums not to exceed seventy-five thousand
dollars, as may be necessary to defray current expenses. The money so borrowed
shall be repaid from such taxes when collected.
Section 24. Same; vote of electors required.
Whenever any sum of money shall be required for any corporate purpose, such
amount or part thereof, within the limitations of this Charter, may be raised
by loan if authorized by a three-fifths vote of the electors voting by ballot
upon the question at a regular or special election.
Section 25. Same; election; submission of proposition; notice.
The proposition to raise an additional amount by tax, as provided in this
Charter, or the propositions to raise by loan money for any corporate purpose,
as provided in the preceding section, shall be submitted to a vote of the
qualified electors at a regular or special election, and notice of the
submission of any such proposition shall be given in such manner and for such
length of time as is provided in this Charter for notices of City elections.
Section 26. Authority to borrow; restriction; bonds; regulations.
No loans shall be made by the Council or by its authority exceeding the amounts
prescribed in this chapter. For any loans lawfully made, the bonds of the City
may be issued bearing a legal rate of interest. A record showing the dates,
numbers and amounts of all bonds issued, and when due, shall be kept by the
City Controller. When deemed necessary by the Council to extend the time of
payment, new bonds may be issued in place of former bonds falling due, in such
manner as merely to change, but not to increase, the indebtedness of the City.
Each bond shall show upon its face the class of indebtedness to which it
belongs, and from what fund it is payable.
Section 27. Bonds; contents; proceeds; use; violations; penalty.
Every bond issued by the City shall contain on its face a statement specifying
the object for which the same is issued, and if issued for the purpose of
raising money for any public improvement, the particular public improvement
shall also be specified on the face of such bond, and it shall be unlawful for
any officer of the City to sign or issue any such bond aforesaid, or to use
bonds or the proceeds from the sale thereof, for any other object than that
mentioned on the face of such bond, and any such officer who shall violate any
of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
Section 28. Total indebtedness; restriction; computation; public utilities;
bonds; regulations.
No indebtedness shall be incurred by the issue of bonds or otherwise in any sum
which, including existing indebtedness, shall exceed eight percent of the
assessed valuation of the real and personal property within the City subject to
taxation as shown by the last preceding assessment roll of the City; provided,
however, that bonds issued for public improvements in connection with which a
special assessment is made to pay therefor and which are a charge upon such
district shall not be included in determining the amount of such indebtedness.
Moneys on hand in the Sinking Fund, limited to the payment of indebtedness, may
be treated as a reduction of such indebtedness to that extent. Whenever the
City is authorized to acquire, own, purchase, construct or operate any public
utility, it may, for the purpose of acquiring, owning, purchasing, constructing
or operating the same, borrow money on the credit of the City. The amount of
money which may be borrowed for any such purpose on the credit of the City
shall not exceed three percent of the assessed valuation of all real and
personal property of the City, and if, as appears by the last preceding United
States census, the City shall attain a population in excess of thirty thousand,
then such sum shall not exceed two percent of the assessed valuation of all the
real and personal property of the City. The City may also, for the purpose of
acquiring, owning, purchasing, constructing or operating such public utility,
issue mortgage bonds therefor beyond the general limits of bonded indebtedness
prescribed by law, provided that such mortgage bonds issued beyond the general
limit of bonded indebtedness prescribed by the law shall not impose any
liability upon the City, but shall be secured only upon the property and
revenue of such public utilities, including a franchise stating the terms upon
which, in case of foreclosure, the purchaser may operate the same, which
franchise shall in no case extend for a longer period than twenty years from
the time of the sale of such utility and franchise on foreclosure. And
provided, further, that in case of the issuance of mortgage bonds, a special
sinking fund shall be created by setting aside such percentage of the gross or
net earnings of the public utility as may be deemed sufficient for the payment
of the mortgage bonds at maturity. The City shall not have power to incur
indebtedness or issue bonds of any kind, except for emergency purposes as
hereinafter provided, and bonds secured only by mortgage on the property and
franchise of the public utility, which shall exceed in the aggregate ten
percent of the assessed valuation of all the real and personal property in the
City.
Section 29. Bonds; Sinking Fund required; exception.
No bonds, except serial bonds which fall due annually, shall be issued without
providing a Sinking Fund to pay them at maturity.
Section 30. Emergencies; authority to borrow; restriction.
In case of fire, flood or other calamity, the Council may borrow, for the
relief of the inhabitants of the City and for the preservation of Municipal
property, a sum, not to exceed one-fourth of one percent of the assessed
valuation of all real and personal property in the City, due in not more than
three years, even if such loan would cause the indebtedness of the City to
exceed the limit fixed in this Charter.
Section 31. Judgments; decrees; payment; authority to issue bonds.
Whenever any judgment or decree of any court shall be rendered or decreed
against the City of Lincoln Park, and said City shall be unable to meet the
payment of such judgment or decree by reason of the limitation of its power of
taxation, then and in such case, it shall be lawful for the Council of said
City to issue the bonds of such City to an amount not exceeding the sum of such
judgment or decree, and the taxed costs arising in the procuring of such
judgment or decree, together with the interest thereon, which bonds may be made
payable at such times and place and at such rate of interest, not exceeding six
percent per annum, as shall be prescribed by the Council, and such bonds shall
be sold and disposed of at not less than par value, in such manner as may be
deemed advisable by said Council.
Section 32. Treasurer's certificate showing sums due; issuance mandatory; fee.
It shall be the duty of the City Treasurer, upon request made by any party, to
issue his certificate showing all unpaid taxes, special assessments, water
rates and other charges that are a lien upon property and which are payable at
his office, and he shall charge the party requesting the same the sum of
twenty-five cents for each parcel, which fee shall be paid into the City
treasury and credited to the General Fund.
Section 33. Taxes; assessments; vacating; Council powers.
The Council shall have the power, when it shall appear that any tax or special
assessment is unjust or is based upon any property not owned by the person to
whom it is assessed, to repay the same out of the proper fund, if collected, or
if not collected, to vacate the tax or assessment, in whole or in part. No such
action on the part of the Council shall in any way affect or invalidate any
other tax or assessment so levied or collected in said City.
Section 34. Drawing from treasury; warrants; signatures required.
No money shall be drawn from the treasury except in pursuance of the authority
and appropriation of the Council, and upon the warrant of the Controller,
countersigned by the Clerk. Such warrant shall specify the fund from which it
is payable, and shall be paid from no other fund. No warrant shall be drawn
upon the treasury after the fund from which it should be paid has been
exhausted. Any such warrant shall be void against the City.
Section 35. Receipts; disbursements; Treasurer's annual statement; contents;
regulations.
On or before the fourth Monday in July of each year the City Treasurer shall
present to the Council a full statement of the receipts and disbursements of
the treasury for the preceding fiscal year ending the 30th day of June of each
year, classifying them therein by the funds to which such receipts are credited
and out of which such disbursements are made, and the balance remaining in each
fund, and at the same time the City Controller shall present to the Council a
full detailed statement of the receipts and disbursements of the City for said
fiscal year, which statement shall distinctly show the amount of all taxes
raised during the year for all purposes, and the amount raised for each fund;
the amount levied by special assessment and the amount collected on each such
assessment; the items and amounts received from all other sources during the
year; also the several items of all expenditures made during the year, and the
objects thereof, classifying the same for each purpose separately. Such
statement shall contain such other information as may be necessary to a full
understanding of the financial concerns of the City. The Council shall examine
such statements and cause the same to be corrected if necessary. Said
statement, signed by the Mayor and Controller, shall be filed in the office of
the Clerk, and a copy thereof published during the last week in August of each
year in the official newspaper or in a newspaper of general circulation in the
City designated by the Council.
CHAPTER VIII
Appropriation of Private Property
Section 1. Authority to condemn property; State law.
Subject to the limitations in this Charter contained, the City shall have power
to appropriate private property, either within or without the City limits, for
public use. All such proceedings shall, at the option of the Council, be taken
in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 149 of the Public Acts of Michigan
of 1911, being Sections 353 to 373, inclusive, of the Compiled Laws of Michigan
of 1915, or in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 75 of the Compiled
Laws of 1915; provided, however, that in the case of appropriation of lands
lying without the corporate limits and necessary for the disposal of sewage or
the obtaining or protecting of a water supply for the City or the inhabitants
thereof, all such proceedings shall be taken in accordance with Chapter 75 of
the Compiled Laws of Michigan of 1915, and the jury shall consist of twelve
freeholders drawn from the body of the County, and if they shall determine such
appropriation is necessary and that the use proposed will not materially injure
the health or safety of the persons living adjacent to the lands, they shall
award the compensation to be paid therefor.
CHAPTER IX
Public Improvements
Section 1. General public improvements defined.
General public improvements are such improvements as are required for the
general use and benefit of the City at large and are to be paid for by the
City: (1) from the proper general fund of the City; (2) by a special tax voted
by the electors for that specific purpose; (3) by the proceeds of general
obligation bonds, authorized by the electors for that specific purpose; (4) in
the case of public utilities, by the proceeds of duly authorized mortgage
bonds; or (5) partly from each of any two or more of the above enumerated
sources of revenue, all subject to the provisions of and limitations prescribed
by this Charter and the general laws of the State.
Section 2. Same; acquisition.
The City may acquire, extend or alter, as the case may be, by purchase, lease,
condemnation or construction, the following general public improvements,
including all necessary lands therefor, to-wit: public buildings necessary or
convenient for the administration of the City; water works, pumping stations,
water mains with hydrants and other necessary equipment; plants for the
purification of water; a system of trunk sewers; plants for the disposal of
sewage; plants for the disposal of garbage; parks; fire engine stations and
necessary equipment therefor, including all necessary fire fighting apparatus;
recreation and play grounds; public toilets and comfort stations; boulevards,
cemeteries, hospitals, almshouses; markets, City prison, police stations,
public libraries; public scales; bridges, permanent structures required to
accomplish the separation of street grades at railroad crossings, including the
necessary approaches thereto and also including any damages allowed to or
recovered by the holders of property abutting thereon; works which involve the
public health or safety; and other general improvements of any nature needed
for public City purposes.
Section 3. Same; transportation facilities.
Subject to the provisions of this Charter, the City may acquire, own, establish
and maintain public utilities for supplying water, heat, light, power and
transportation to the City, and to the inhabitants thereof; and may also
acquire, own, improve, maintain, construct and operate parks, boulevards,
cemeteries, hospitals, almshouses and plants necessary for the disposal of
sewage and garbage and all other works which involve the public health and
safety and also any land necessary for such improvement or for use in
connection with any other proper public purposes either within or without its
corporate limits; provided, however, that the City shall not acquire any
facilities for transportation until the City shall have a population of twenty-
five thousand or more and such transportation facilities shall not extend more
than three miles from the limits of the City, and then only for the purpose of
making necessary connections with other transportation lines in order to reach
parks or institutions owned or operated by the City.
Section 4. Public utilities; acquisitions; submission of proposal to electors
required.
The City shall have no power to acquire any public utility, unless the
proposition to acquire such public utility shall have first received an
affirmative vote of three-fifths of the qualified electors of the City voting
thereon at any regular, special or Municipal election, provided, however, that
only those works, improvements and utilities designed or used for the supplying
of water, heat, light and power and transportation to the Municipality and the
inhabitants thereof shall be deemed public utilities falling within the
restrictions of this section.
Section 5. Water, light, etc.; power to purchase.
The City shall have the power to purchase from adjacent or neighboring
municipalities, or from private corporations or individuals, water, light, heat
and power; but the City shall acquire no system of water mains or conduits, nor
of electric light poles, wires, etc., nor a system of mains, conduits, or poles
and wires for supplying heat, light and power, unless the City itself purchases
such water, light, heat and power, uses the same or part of the same itself and
resells the balance thereof to the inhabitants of the City.
Section 6. "General public improvements"; "alteration"; construed.
All public improvements hereinabove provided for, either by specific mention or
by implication, shall be considered general public improvements; provided,
however, that the term "alteration" shall not include ordinary repairs and
upkeep thereof. The cost and expense of acquiring the foregoing permanent
public improvements shall be paid by the City. Alterations and extension of
general public improvements shall be made and paid for in the manner herein
provided for the acquisition of such improvement.
Section 7. Special assessment improvement defined; costs.
Special assessment improvements are improvements of such a local character that
the cost thereof is chargeable to lands and tenements deriving special benefits
from the installation of such improvements. The cost thereof may be paid wholly
by the City, or partly by the City and partly by special assessment districts
constituted of lands abutting upon or adjacent to such improvements, or wholly
by such special assessment districts. The City's portion, if any, of the cost
of any special assessment improvement, shall be paid for by the City: (1) from
the proper general fund of the City; (2) by a special tax voted by the electors
for that specific purpose; (3) by the proceeds of general obligation bonds of
the City, not exceeding forty percent of the entire cost of such improvement;
or partly from each of any two or more of such sources of revenue; all subject
to the provisions of and limitations prescribed by this Charter and the general
laws of the State.
Section 8. Special assessment improvements; Council powers; requisites.
The power to provide for a special assessment improvement shall be in the
Council; provided, however, that the Council shall provide for any special
assessment improvement when there is filed with the Clerk a petition signed by
the owners of at least fifty percent of the lands abutting upon or adjacent to
such improvement and benefited thereby.
Section 9. Same; petition; contents, etc.
Such petition shall specifically describe the improvement which it is desired
to have constructed and may set forth the type of construction; but the Council
may adopt such type of construction as it deems best. Such petition shall have
attached thereto the affidavit of each signer of the petition in which
affidavit he shall prescribe the parcels of land owned by him and certify his
ownership thereof; also the affidavit or affidavits of persons with knowledge
certifying that the signatures attached to such petition are the genuine
signatures of those persons whose signatures they purport to be. Said petition
shall be filed with the City Clerk.
Section 10. Same; Council duties upon presentation of petition.
At its first regular meeting thereafter, the Clerk shall present to the Council
said petition, and said Council shall immediately investigate or cause to be
investigated the sufficiency of said petition. Upon the completion of such
investigation, the Council shall, by resolution, determine the sufficiency
thereof, and its said determination shall be final and conclusive.
Section 11. Same; waters; sewers; pro rata assessment required.
Special assessments made for the purpose of paying the whole or a portion of
the cost of any lateral sewer, trunk sewer, water mains, drains or watercourse,
or of acquiring or widening any street, alley or public place, shall be
assessed pro rata and according to the benefits derived from such improvement
by each parcel of land in the special assessment district.
Section 12. Same; paving; assessment according to frontage required.
Special assessment made for the purpose of paying the whole or a portion of the
cost of paving any street, alley or public place shall be assessed pro rata and
according to the benefits derived from such improvement by each parcel of land
in the special assessment district; provided, however, that if from the shape
or size of any such parcel, an assessment thereon according to its frontage
would be unjust and disproportionate to the assessment on the other parcels of
land, the Assessor making the assessment may assess such parcel of land for
such number of feet of frontage as in his opinion will be just. (Amended April
4, 1955)
Section 13. Sewers, etc.; streets, alleys, etc.; reconstruction; repaving;
cost.
The cost of repaving any street, alley or public place, excepting sidewalks and
reconstruction of a lateral sewer, drain and watercourse, shall be paid by the
City.
(Amended April 6, 1931)
Section 14. Paving defined.
The term "paving" shall include not only the paving of a street, alley or
public place, but also the guttering or curbing thereof, and the installation
of such drains and manholes as may be necessary to drain the surface of such
street, alley or public place of all storm and other waters.
Section 15. Public improvements; resolution required; contents; plans,
estimates, etc. 
Whenever the Council desires to acquire or provide for a public improvement, it
shall so declare by resolution, and in said resolution shall describe the
improvement and, if the improvement be a special assessment improvement, shall
describe the special assessment district to be specially assessed, either by
