Ch. 868
824.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Bakery" means an establishment wherein bread, cakes and/or pastries
are prepared, baked and/or sold at wholesale or retail.
   (b)   "Bulk food establishment" means any establishment where food in bulk,
package, metal, pasteboard, glass or plastic container is held, stored or
offered for sale.
   (c)   "Capacity" means the maximum number of seating facilities for patrons.
   (d)   "Employee" means any person who handles food or drink during
preparation or serving, who comes in contact with eating or cooking utensils or
who is employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served.
   (e)   "Health Department" means the County Health Department.
   (f)   "Health Officer" means the County Health Department or, if such
Department ceases to exist or ceases to make the inspections or health
examinations required by this chapter, the Health Officer of the City or his or
her authorized representative.
   (g)   "Itinerant restaurant" means a restaurant operating for a temporary
period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition or
similar gathering.
   (h)   "Restaurant" means a restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short-order
cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain and all other eating
or drinking establishments, as well as kitchens or other places in which food
or drink is prepared for sale on the premises or elsewhere.
   (i)   "Utensils" means any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery,
containers or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during
storage, preparation or serving.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.010)
824.02 LICENSES REQUIRED; POSTING.
   No person who does not possess an unrevoked license of current issue, as
provided in this chapter, shall operate a restaurant in the City. Such license
shall be posted in a conspicuous place. Only persons who comply with this
chapter shall be entitled to receive and retain such a license. A person
conducting an itinerant restaurant shall also be required to secure a license.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.020)
824.03 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   (a)   A written application for a license required by this chapter shall be
made to the City Clerk on a form provided at the office of the City Clerk.
   (b)   The applicant shall furnish, on forms supplied by the City Clerk, the
following:
      (1)   A statement as to whether the applicant is a person, partnership,
firm, corporation or organization;
      (2)   Names and addresses of the person, members of the partnership or
officers of the firm, corporation or organization making application;
      (3)   The name and address of the restaurant;
      (4)   The type of restaurant;
      (5)   The capacity of the dining room;
      (6)   Plans and specifications for new construction or for alterations of
existing restaurants, which plans and specifications shall be submitted to the
Health Department for approval before the issuance of a building or
construction permit;
      (7)   An agreement to permit the Health Officer to inspect the restaurant
and everything in connection with it and to interview the employees at any
reasonable time, and a statement that the applicant will give true and complete
information to the Health Officer concerning the operation of the restaurant;
      (8)   The date of the application; and
      (9)   The signature of the applicant.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.030)
824.04 INVESTIGATIONS.
   (a)   The City Clerk shall, upon receiving an application for a license
required by this chapter, refer it to the County Health Department for
investigation of the facts stated in the application and the sanitary
conditions in and around the place wherein it is proposed to operate the
restaurant specified in the application.
   (b)   If it is found by the Department, after investigation, that the
statements contained in the application are true and that the existing sanitary
conditions in the place wherein it is proposed to operate the restaurant
conform to the sanitary requirements of this chapter, the Department shall
approve the application and return it to the City Clerk, who shall issue a
license to the applicant permitting him or her to operate the type of
restaurant designated in the application, and no other, upon payment of a fee
as provided in Section
824.06.
   (c)   If it is found by the Department, after investigation, that the
statements contained in the application are not true or that the applicant is
not operating or cannot operate a restaurant conforming to the sanitary
requirements of this chapter, the Department shall disapprove the application
and return it to the City Clerk with a detailed statement of the reasons for
such disapproval.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.040)
824.05 REJECTION; HEARINGS.
   (a)   The City Clerk shall, upon receipt of an application for a license
required by this chapter that has been disapproved, present it to Council at
its first regular meeting which will allow the serving of ten days notice upon
the applicant, and shall, on or before the ten days before such regular
meeting, serve or cause to be served upon the applicant a notice of disapproval
of the application by the County Health Department and the date of the regular
meeting at which the same will be presented to Council.
   (b)   Council shall consider the disapproval of the Health Department, shall
hear the applicant in his or her behalf and shall act upon the application.
Council shall establish its own rules of order for such review and hearing.
   (c)   If the application is denied by Council, the City Clerk shall give
written notice to the applicant within five days of such denial and such
applicant shall not open the restaurant designated in the application to the
public thereafter.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.050)
824.06 LICENSE FEE; TERM; TRANSFERABILITY; RENEWALS.
   (a)   The fee for a license required by this chapter shall be twenty dollars
($20.00) per year or fraction thereof for each separate restaurant, provided
that no fee shall be charged for a license granted to a fraternal, religious,
educational or social organization.
(Res. 83-128. Passed 2-14-83.)
   (b)   All licenses shall expire on the May 1 following their issuance,
unless revoked, and shall not be transferable or assignable. All applications
for license renewal shall be made at least thirty days before the license
expires.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.060)
824.07 SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSES.
   (a)   The Health Officer may revoke or suspend the license of any restaurant
which is not or cannot be operated in conformity with this chapter by giving
written notice to the licensee, stating therein the reasons for such action of
suspension or revocation. A copy of such notice shall be sent to the licensing
authority.
   (b)   In the event of such suspension or revocation, the licensee shall be
entitled to a hearing before Council if the licensee presents a request for
such hearing, in writing, to the City Clerk, within ten days from the date of
such revocation or suspension. Such hearing shall be started at the following
regular meeting of Council, and Council, after hearing and considering both
sides of the case, shall act as sole judge of whether or not the revocation or
suspension shall take effect. Council shall establish its own rules of order
for such review.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.070)
824.08 COMPLIANCE WITH SANITARY REGULATIONS REQUIRED.
   Every restaurant, bulk food establishment and bakery shall comply with all
of the items of sanitation set forth in this chapter.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.080)
824.09 FLOORS, WALLS AND CEILINGS.
   (a)   The floors of all rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared or
served or in which utensils are washed shall be of such construction as to be
easily cleaned, shall be smooth and shall be kept clean and in good repair.
   (b)   Walls and ceilings of all rooms shall be kept clean and in good
repair. All walls and ceilings of rooms in which food or drink is prepared
shall be finished in a light color. The walls of all rooms in which food or
drink is prepared or utensils are washed shall have a smooth, washable surface.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.090)
824.10 DOORS AND WINDOWS.
   When flies are prevalent, all openings into the outer air shall be
effectively screened and doors shall be self-closing unless other effective
means are provided to prevent the entrance of flies.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.100)
824.11 LIGHTING AND VENTILATION.
   (a)   All rooms in which food or drink is stored or prepared or in which
utensils are washed shall be well lighted.
   (b)   All rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared or served or in
which utensils are washed shall be well ventilated.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.110)
824.12 TOILET FACILITIES.
   (a)   Every restaurant, bulk food establishment and/or bakery shall be
provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its
employees, conforming with the State Plumbing Code. Toilet rooms shall not open
directly into any food processing room. The doors of all toilet rooms shall be
self-closing. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair
and well lighted and ventilated. Handwashing signs shall be posted in each
toilet room used by employees. Restaurants and establishments serving alcoholic
beverages shall provide proper and adequate toilet facilities for patrons.
Separate toilet facilities shall be provided for each sex and adequate urinals
shall be provided in men's toilets. The number of fixtures provided shall be on
the basis of the seating capacity of the establishment.
   (b)   All toilet rooms shall be properly vented by exterior windows or
mechanical means to the outside air.
   (c)   All toilet rooms and passageways leading to the same shall be well
lighted.
   (d)   All toilet rooms shall be kept clean. Sanitary toilet paper shall be
provided.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.120)
824.13 LAVATORY FACILITIES.
   Adequate and convenient handwashing facilities shall be provided, including
hot and cold running water, soap and dispenser and approved sanitary towels.
The use of a common towel is prohibited. No employee shall resume work after
using the toilet room without first washing his or her hands. Handwashing signs
shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.130)
824.14 WATER SUPPLY.
   Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in
which food is prepared or utensils are washed. The water supply shall be
adequate, of a safe, sanitary quality, and approved by the State Department of
Public Health. An adequate supply of running hot water shall be piped to all
sinks. Where a storage tank is used, the minimum capacity shall be thirty
gallons.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.140)
824.15 UTENSILS AND EQUIPMENT.
   (a)   Construction. All multi-use utensils, showcases, display cases or
windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerating equipment, sinks and other
equipment or utensils used in connection with the preparation of food shall be
so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair.
Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be used, provided
that solder containing lead may be used for jointing. Metal sinks shall be
provided for the purpose of cleaning utensils and tools used in the handling,
display or dispensing of food. All worktables and benches must be of a tight,
smooth material, free from cracks and easily cleaned.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.150)
   (b)   Cleaning. All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters,
shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods and sinks shall be kept clean and
free from dust, dirt, insects and other contaminating material. All cloths used
by waiters, chefs and other employees shall be clean. Single-service containers
shall be used only once. All multi-service eating and drinking utensils shall
be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal
process after each usage. All multi-use utensils used in the preparation of
food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an
approved bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation. Drying
cloths, if used, shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose. No
article, polish or other substance containing any cyanide preparation or other
poisonous material shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of utensils.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.160)
   (c)   Storage and Handling. After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be
stored in a clean, dry place which is protected from flies, dust and other
contamination and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination
as far as practicable. Single-service utensils shall be purchased only in
sanitary containers, shall be stored therein in a clean, dry place until used
and shall be handled in a sanitary manner.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.170)
824.16 GARBAGE AND RUBBISH.
   All wastes shall be properly disposed of and all garbage and trash shall be
kept in suitable receptacles in a manner so as not to become a nuisance.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.180)
824.17 FOOD AND DRINK.
   (a)   Wholesomeness. All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome, free from
spoilage and so prepared as to be safe for human consumption. All milk, fluid
milk products, ice cream and other frozen desserts shall be from approved
sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual
original containers in which they were received from the distributor or from a
bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device, provided that this
requirement shall not apply to cream which may be served from the original
bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service. All oysters, clams and
mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked, shall be kept until
used in the containers in which they were placed.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.190)
   (b)   Storage and Serving.
      (1)   All food and drink shall be so stored, displayed and served as to
be protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents,
unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage and other
contamination. No animals or fowls shall be kept or allowed in any room in
which food or drink is prepared or stored. All means necessary for the
elimination of flies, roaches and rodents shall be used. All food stored shall
be elevated at least twelve inches above the floor, unless packaged in
watertight containers, and shall be free of possible sources of contamination.
No food shall be stored below sewer lines.
      (2)   All readily perishable food and drink shall be kept at or below
fifty degrees Fahrenheit except when being prepared or served. Wastewater from
refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.200)
824.18 EMPLOYEE CLEANLINESS; FOODHANDLER'S CERTIFICATES REQUIRED.
   (a)   All employees shall wear clean garments and shall keep their hands
clean at all times while engaged in handling food, drink, utensils or
equipment.
   (b)   Employees shall not expectorate or use tobacco in any form in rooms in
which food is prepared.
   (c)   All employees shall have foodhandler's certificates of current issue.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.210)
824.19 LITTERING; USE OF FACILITIES; SOILED CLOTHING.
   (a)   The premises of all establishments covered by this chapter shall be
kept clean and free of litter or rubbish.
   (b)   None of the operations connected with any such establishment shall be
conducted in any room used as living or sleeping quarters.
   (c)   Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employees'
clothing and shall be kept clean.
   (d)   Soiled linens, coats and aprons shall be kept in containers provided
for this purpose.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.220)
824.20 ITINERANT RESTAURANTS.
   Itinerant restaurants shall be constructed and operated in an approved
manner.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.230)
824.21 BAKERIES.
   Bakeries shall be subject to the following additional regulations:
   (a)   Metal sinks shall be provided to thoroughly clean mixing bowls, pots,
pans, fixtures and parts of machinery used in the preparation of baked goods.
Sinks shall be large enough to receive the largest utensil used. Brushes shall
be used to aid in the cleaning process.
   (b)   Frying kettles shall be placed at least one foot from any wall, and
the wall shall be protected by a smooth, nonporous metal shield to splash
height. A hood shall be provided and suspended at least seven feet above the
floor, shall extend at least one foot beyond the edge of the frying kettle and
shall be vented to the outside air and equipped with a fan or blower capable of
removing all smoke, odors and vapor. No vent over a sidewalk will be permitted.
   (c)   "Custard mix" and "custard filler," as used in this subsection, refers
to any product consisting principally of flour, sugar, eggs and milk, with or
without cornstarch, heated, cooled and applied to pastry without subsequent
heating. This subsection shall also apply to custard filled pastry commonly
designated as creampuffs and eclairs which may be heated subsequent to filling.
      The entire custard mix to be used in the manufacture of custard filled
pastry shall be brought to a temperature of not less than 200 degrees
Fahrenheit, shall be maintained at not less than that temperature for not less
than ten minutes and, within one hour thereafter, shall be placed in a
refrigerating temperature of not over fifty degrees Fahrenheit and kept at or
below such temperature until applied to the pastry.
      No custard filled pastry shall be sold at either wholesale or retail, or
transported for retail delivery, unless it bears, prominently displayed on the
outside thereof, in legible letters, the name of the manufacturing baker, the
day of manufacture and the following statement: "REFRIGERATE."
      No custard filled pastry shall be kept, displayed or offered for sale in
or from any bakery, store, place or vehicle unless it has been refrigerated at
a temperature of not over fifty degrees Fahrenheit from the time of manufacture
until the time of delivery to the consumer.
   (d)   Only wholesome ingredients shall be used in the preparation of baked
goods.
   (e)   No baked goods shall be exposed to dust, dirt or other contamination.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.240)
824.22 EXAMINATION OF FOOD AND DRINK.
   Samples of food, drink and other substances may be taken and examined by the
Health Officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of
unwholesomeness or adulteration. The Health Officer may condemn and forbid the
sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink which is
unwholesome or adulterated.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.250)
824.23 DISEASED EMPLOYEES PROHIBITED.
   No person who is affected with any disease in a communicable form or is a
carrier of such disease shall work in any restaurant. No restaurant shall
employ any such person or any person who is suspected of being affected with
any disease in a communicable form or of being a carrier of such disease. If
the restaurant manager suspects that any employee has contracted any disease in
a communicable form or has become a carrier of such disease, he or she shall
immediately notify the Health Officer. A placard containing this section shall
be posted in all toilet rooms.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.260)
824.24 PERIODIC INSPECTIONS; NOTICES OF VIOLATIONS; CORRECTION.
   The Health Officer shall have the authority and duty to enforce this chapter
as follows:
   (a)   At least once every six months, or as often as necessary, the Health
Officer shall inspect every restaurant located in the City. The Health Officer
may enter any building or part thereof which is used or which he or she has
reason to believe is used for the storage, preparation, sale, serving or
distribution of food or drink for human consumption to inspect the premises,
furniture, equipment, dishes or utensils used therein and to determine whether
or not the sanitary requirements of this chapter are complied with.
   (b)   If, on inspection, the Health Officer finds any violation of this
chapter, he or she shall issue an order to the licensee or person in charge of
the restaurant directing the correction of such violation within such
reasonable time as the Health Officer deems proper.
   (c)   If the Health Officer finds a continuation of the violation upon a
second inspection after such reasonable time, he or she shall suspend the
license of the restaurant until such violation is corrected.
   (d)   If the Health Officer finds unsanitary conditions in any restaurant
such that it would be immediately dangerous to the health of the general
public, he or she may immediately suspend the license of and close the
restaurant until such unsanitary conditions are corrected, following which
suspension and closure he or she shall give a written notice in a reasonable
time to the licensee or responsible representative in charge stating his or her
reasons for closing the restaurant. Continuing to operate after receipt of such
written notice constitutes a violation of this chapter.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.34.270)
824.99 PENALTY AND SANCTIONS FOR MUNICIPAL CIVIL INFRACTIONS.
   Whoever violates the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the
penalty and sanctions for Municipal civil infractions as provided in Section
202.101 of the Administration Code.
(Res. 03-57A. Passed 1-27-03.)
CHAPTER 826
Food Trucks
826.01   License required; definitions.
826.02   License application.
826.03   License issuance; investigations.
826.04   License fees.
826.05   Limitations on issuance of licenses.
826.06   License card; stickers.
826.07   License expiration.
826.08   License revocation.
826.09   Appeals.
826.10   Regulations.
826.11   Garbage and rubbish.
826.12   Location permit.
826.13   Food truck zones.
826.99   Penalty.
826.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any food truck to operate in the City without
first obtaining a license therefor from the City Clerk.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
   (b)   Definitions.
      (1)   “Food Truck” means any motorized or non-motorized vehicle, trailer
or other device designed to be portable and not permanently attached to the
ground from which food is vended, served, displayed or offered for sale.
      (2)   “Food Truck License” means an annual license must be obtained by
all food trucks to operate within the City.
      (3)   “Food Truck Location Permit” means authorization for a licensed
food truck to operate on private property or public property not included in a
designated Food Truck Zone. A letter of permission from the property owner must
be presented at the time of application. Regulations for these permits will be
subject to safety requirements from the Building & Fire Departments.
      (4)   “Food Truck Zone” means an area of City-owned property designated
by the Council, where licensed food trucks are allowed to park and operate
without obtaining a location permit.
(Res. 2023-099A. Passed 4-3-23, Eff. 4-13-23.)
826.02 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Before any license required by this chapter is issued, the applicant shall
file with the City Clerk a written application for such license, setting forth
the following:
   (a)   The full name of the business, the business address, the name of the
business owner, and the home address, phone number and birth date of the
business owner and any other information deemed necessary by the City Clerk;
   (b)   A copy of the license issued by the State of Michigan;
   (c)   A copy of the license issued by the Wayne County Health Department;
   (d)   Proof of insurance in an amount not less than $1,000,000 for property
damage and injuries, including injury resulting in death caused by the
operation of the food truck, naming the City of Lincoln Park as an additional
insured.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.03 LICENSE ISSUANCE; INVESTIGATIONS.
   Upon the filing of a license application, and the payment of the appropriate
fee, the following procedure shall be followed before such license shall be
issued:
   (a)   The applicant shall have all motor vehicles used in the course of
business inspected for safety and fitness by the Traffic Division of the Police
Department and the Fire Inspector. Said applicant shall present a current
Michigan Department of State driver's license and proof of vehicle registration
and insurance with the application. The applicant shall have the fire
suppression system tested by the Fire Inspector or provide proof of a valid
test from another municipality.
   (b)   The City Clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued
under this chapter.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21; Res. 2023-099A. Passed 4-3-23, Eff. 4-13-23.)
826.04 LICENSE FEES.
   Before any license required by this chapter is issued, the applicant shall
pay to the City Treasurer the fee required as set from time to time by Council
resolution.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.05 LIMITATIONS ON ISSUANCE OF LICENSES.
   No license required by this chapter shall be issued to any person who has
been convicted of a felony or to any person who has been convicted of any
misdemeanor pertaining to a sexual deviation or moral turpitude, except that
the Mayor and Council may order the City Clerk to issue a license when it
appears to the Mayor and Council that such applicant is presently a law abiding
citizen and that the issuance of the license is not likely to adversely affect
the health, welfare, morals or safety of the people of the City. However,
nothing contained in this section shall be interpreted to exempt the person
issued a license pursuant to this chapter from complying with all of the other
requirements of this chapter and other ordinance provisions of the City.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.06 LICENSE CARD; STICKERS.
   Upon full compliance by the applicant with the terms and conditions set
forth in Sections
826.02 through
826.04, the City Clerk shall issue to the applicant a license to engage in
business within the City under the terms and conditions of this chapter, and at
the same time the City Clerk shall issue one pocket card, of a design to be
changed each year, bearing the number of the license and the words "Food Truck
Operator License, City of Lincoln Park," which card must at all times be
carried by the licensee while he or she is engaged in the conduct of his or her
business within the City. A sticker shall be issued to any vehicle used by the
licensee after passing inspection under Section
826.03(b), and after paying an inspection fee as set from time to time by
Council resolution. Such sticker shall be prominently displayed on such
vehicle.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.07 LICENSE EXPIRATION.
   A license issued under this chapter shall expire at 12:00 midnight on the
first Tuesday in May following its issuance, unless it expires at an earlier
date under the terms thereof.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.08 LICENSE REVOCATION.
   For any violation of the conditions of any license issued under this
chapter, Council may revoke any license after a hearing given to the licensee.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.09 APPEALS
   A licensee whose license under this chapter has been suspended or revoked
may appeal by filing a written notice of appeal with the City Council.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.10 REGULATIONS.
   Licensees engaged in business within the City under this chapter shall
comply with the following regulations, which regulations shall be printed upon
the back of the license issued by the City Clerk:
   (a)   Every licensee, upon the request of any person shall exhibit the
license issued by the City Clerk and permit such person to examine the same.
   (b)   Every licensee shall exhibit his or her license to any police officer,
marshal, or officer of the City upon demand.
   (c)   Food trucks shall be located on a hard bituminous surface and shall
not be located within 25 feet of any handicapped parking space or impede access
to the entrance or driveway of any adjacent building.
   (d)   No licensee shall sound any device which produces a loud or raucous
noise, or use or operate any loudspeaker, public address system, radio, sound
amplifier or similar device to attract public attention that exceed the levels
as prescribed in Chapter
1294.31(a)
   (e)   No licensee shall conduct business in such a way as would increase
traffic congestion or constitute a hazard to life or property or obstruct
access to emergency vehicles.
   (f)   No licensee shall set up on any private property within the City
without the consent of the owner thereof or some person having authority to
grant such permission. The licensee shall provide written consent from the
owner thereof or some person having authority to grant such permission. The
licensee shall provide written consent from the owner and obtain a Location
Permit from the City Clerk's office.
(Res. 2023-099A. Passed 4-3-23, Eff. 4-13-23.)
   (g)   No licensee shall set up on any property within 150 feet of a
restaurant/food establishment without the written permission of the owner of
said establishment.
   (h)   No licensee shall, during school hours, sell upon the streets, alleys,
or public places of the City contiguous or adjacent to any property used for
school purposes and within 200 feet of such property, without written
permission from the Superintendent of Schools.
   (i)   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any merchandise upon the
streets, alleys, or public places within the City during the hours of 10:00
p.m. and 7:00 a.m. as prescribed in Chapter
666.04.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.11 GARBAGE AND RUBBISH.
   Each food truck shall be equipped with a receptacle for the disposal of
wrappers, papers, envelopes, or other containers. The operator shall pick up
such wrappers, papers and envelopes accumulating within 25 feet after any sale
or delivery of his or her products.
(Res. 2021-100A. Passed 4-19-21.)
826.12 LOCATION PERMIT.
   Location permits shall be required by licensed owners for operation on
private property and public property not included in a designated Food Truck
Zone. The City Clerk shall issue a location permit to the owner within 2
business days of a completed application. The rules and regulations for
obtaining a Location Permit shall be set from time to time by the Council.
(Res. 2023-099A. Passed 4-3-23, Eff. 4-13-23.)
826.13 FOOD TRUCK ZONES.
   Mayor and Council may designate specific Food Truck Zones on city owned
property for licensed owners to operate their food trucks without a permit.
Rules and regulations regarding these zones shall be set from time to time by
the Council.
(Res. 2023-099A. Passed 4-3-23, Eff. 4-13-23.)
826.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 828
Gaming Establishments
828.01   License required.
828.02   License application; citizenship required.
828.03   License fees.
828.04   Conditions for suspension or revocation of licenses.
828.05   Notice of revocability.
828.06   License expiration; revocation by Council.
828.07   Hours of operation; gambling.
828.08   Interior views required.
828.09   Entrances and exits.
828.10   Exceptions to chapter.
828.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Minors - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 722.51 et seq., 750.141
   Ordinances - see M.C.L.A. Sec. 750.141
   Pool and billiard rooms - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 750.141, 750.146, 750.147
   Gambling - see M.C.L.A. Sec. 750.305a
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Carnivals, circuses and exhibitions - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 810
   Gambling in arcades - see B.R. & T.
850.07
   Mechanical amusement devices - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 852
   Gambling in restaurants - see B.R. & T.
868.12
828.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall establish, maintain or operate in the City any billiard
parlor, poolroom, bowling alley or other place for the playing at games by the
public without first obtaining a license therefor from Council.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.010)
828.02 LICENSE APPLICATION; CITIZENSHIP REQUIRED.
   (a)   An application for a license required by this chapter shall be made to
Council and shall be filed with the City Clerk for presentation to Council. The
application shall set forth the full name of the applicant and of every person
interested in the issue of the license applied for, together with the business
and residence addresses of such persons. If the applicant is a corporation,
this provision shall apply only to the officers and directors of the
corporation. Each application shall also set forth the place where it is
proposed to establish, maintain or operate the devices for which a license is
asked and the number of devices to be so established, maintained or operated.
   (b)   No such license shall be granted to any person who is not a citizen of
the United States.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.020)
828.03 LICENSE FEES.
   (a)   Before any license is issued under this chapter, the applicant shall
pay to the City Clerk a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year
for establishing, maintaining or operating a billiard parlor, poolroom, bowling
alley or place of playing at public games. However, where there are more than
one billiard table, more than one pool table or more than five bowling alleys,
an additional sum of five dollars ($5.00) shall be paid for each additional
bowling alley in excess of five, and an additional sum of two dollars ($2.00)
shall be paid for each additional billiard table or pool table in excess of
one.
   (b)   The payment of the sum set forth in subsection (a) hereof shall
entitle the licensee to establish, maintain and operate the devices and places
licensed for one year, subject to this chapter.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.030)
828.04 CONDITIONS FOR SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES.
   The Mayor shall, in his or her discretion, suspend for any period or
indefinitely any license required by this chapter, or revoke the same entirely,
if he or she is satisfied that any billiard parlor, poolroom, bowling alley or
other place for the playing at games by the public, for which such license is
issued, is kept in any respect in disregard or violation of the laws or
ordinances of the City, or that drunkenness, disorder, gaming, gambling,
profanity, obscenity or the sale or consumption of intoxicating liquor is
permitted or tolerated therein.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.040)
828.05 NOTICE OF REVOCABILITY.
   Any license issued pursuant to this chapter shall contain a provision that
the same is issued subject to suspension and revocation by the Mayor as set
forth in Section
828.04.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.050)
828.06 LICENSE EXPIRATION; REVOCATION BY COUNCIL.
   All licenses granted under this chapter shall expire at 12:00 midnight of
the first Tuesday in May following their issuance. Licenses issued under this
chapter may be revoked by Council for a violation of this chapter, any State or
Federal law or any reasonable police regulation of Council generally imposed
upon licensees under this chapter.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.060)
828.07 HOURS OF OPERATION; GAMBLING.
   (a)   Places of public amusement licensed under this chapter shall be closed
to the public from 12:00 midnight until 6:00 a.m. However, establishments
licensed under this chapter which have more than six billiard and/or pool
tables shall be closed from 1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. Quiet and good order shall
be maintained upon the premises and adjacent street, and no person shall be
permitted to loiter or stand in or about the doorway or in front of the
premises.
   (b)   No person shall be permitted to play any game on which a bet or wager
is laid, and no person shall be permitted to lay any wager or bet on the
outcome or result of any game played on the premises.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.070)
   (c)   The operator of a bowling alley may extend the time for the closing of
the bowling alley to 3:00 a.m. However, if such bowling alley is located in a
residential neighborhood, the peace and good order of the neighborhood shall
not be disturbed, and where an intoxicating liquor business is operated in
connection with such bowling alley, the same shall be completely shut and
closed off from the bowling alley at and during the time fixed by law for the
closing hours of such liquor establishment.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.080)
828.08 INTERIOR VIEWS REQUIRED.
   In every billiard parlor or poolroom, the windows in front of the building
shall permit anyone to view the entire interior of the premises from the
outside front of the building, and no partitions shall be permitted which
provide a closed room, except that toilet rooms shall be partitioned off and
shall be of reasonable size.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.090)
828.09 ENTRANCES AND EXITS.
   No building or building structure occupied or used for or in connection with
the operation of a billiard parlor, bowling alley, poolroom or place for
playing public games shall be arranged or laid out so as to provide entrance to
or exit from another part of such building or building structure used or
operated by any other business, unless such entrance or exit shall, at all
times, be kept open for free and ready access by members of the Police
Department in connection with the public inspection of the operation of such
business. There shall be no room separated from the room in which such billiard
parlor, poolroom, bowling alley or place for playing public games is operated
where such room is used in connection with such business, or any other business
where entrance to such room is provided through or from the room in which such
billiard parlor, poolroom, bowling alley or place for playing games is
operated, unless such entrance is at all times open to free and ready access to
members of the Police Department in connection with public inspection of the
premises.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.08.100)
828.10 EXCEPTIONS TO CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall not apply to any amusement or entertainment conducted
under the supervision of:
   (a)   Any public or parochial school, any church or the City, and
organizations under the control or direction of, or supported in whole or in
part by, any such school, church or the City;
   (b)   The Young Men's Christian Association;
   (c)   The Young Women's Christian Association;
   (d)   Any fraternal society when such amusement is open to members only, and
not open to the public; or
   (e)   Religious services of any kind.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.06.010)
828.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 830
Garage, Yard, Basement and Rummage Sales
830.01   Definitions.
830.02   Intent.
830.03   Permitted locations.
830.04   Permit required; application; fee.
830.05   Limitations on permit issuance; display.
830.06   Signs.
830.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Secondhand dealers - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.401 et seq.; B.R. & T.
Ch. 870
   Junk yards - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.451 et seq.
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Junk dealers - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 842
   Sidewalk sales - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 872
   Signs on sidewalks - see S.U. & P.S.
1020.05
830.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, "garage sale," "yard sale," "basement sale" and
"rummage sale," including any similar terms such as "attic sale," "lawn sale,"
"flea market sale," etc., means any sale of tangible personal property, whether
used, secondhand, damaged or discarded, not otherwise regulated in these
Codified Ordinances, advertised by any means whereby the public at large is or
can be aware of such sale.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.74.010)
830.02 INTENT.
   It is the intent of this chapter to regulate the term and frequency of
personal property sales in residential areas so that the residential
environment of such areas is not disturbed or disrupted, and to prohibit the
infringement of any business into such established areas. It is not the intent
of this chapter to seek control of sales by individuals selling five or less of
their household or personal items.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.74.020)
830.03 PERMITTED LOCATIONS.
   An owner, tenant or lessee of a residence or charitable institution,
including churches, schools and hospitals, may conduct a sale as described in
this chapter upon the premises of his or her residence or upon the premises of
such charitable institution, as provided in this chapter.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.74.040)
830.04 PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE.
   No owner, tenant or lessee of a residence or charitable institution shall
conduct, advertise or promote a sale as regulated in this chapter without first
obtaining a permit therefor as provided in this section:
   (a)   A written application shall be filed with the City Clerk, on forms
prescribed by the City Clerk, containing the following:
      (1)   The name and address of the person conducting the sale;
      (2)   The location at which the sale is to be conducted;
      (3)   The number of days which the sale is to be conducted within the
limits prescribed in this chapter;
      (4)   A description of the items proposed to be sold; and
      (5)   The date, nature and location of any past sale conducted by the
applicant.
   (b)   An affidavit signed by the applicant affirming that the items to be
sold are the sole property of such applicant must be filed with the
application.
   (c)   The applicant shall pay the sum of three dollars ($3.00) for the
issuance of the sale permit to the City Clerk at the time of filing the
application.
830.05 LIMITATIONS ON PERMIT ISSUANCE; DISPLAY.
   (a)   Any sale as described in this chapter shall not be conducted for
longer than three consecutive days. The City Clerk shall not issue more than
two permits per calendar year, per location or residence, for any sale
described in this chapter.
(Res. 91-216. Passed 4-15-91.)
   (b)   The permit authorizing such sale shall be displayed in a front window
or other prominent place, clearly visible from the street, at each location
where a sale is being conducted.
   (c)   The items offered for sale shall not be displayed in the front yard of
such premises.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.74.060)
830.06 SIGNS.
   (a)   Signs advertising a sale regulated by this chapter may be erected or
placed on the premises of the sale beginning on the first day of the sale and
shall be removed immediately at the end of the third day.
   (b)   No sign may be placed on the City easement between the sidewalk and
the curb.
   (c)   Signs advertising a sale regulated by this chapter may be placed on
the applicant's vehicle, which is legally parked on the City streets, between
the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., after which time the signs must be
removed from the vehicle. At no time will these signs interfere with any
vehicle visibility.
   (d)   No sign shall be in excess of six square feet and no sign shall be
illuminated in any manner whatsoever, except incidentally by street lights or
house lights.
   (e)   The posting of garage sale, yard sale or basement sale signs is not
considered to be display advertising, as otherwise defined in these Codified
Ordinances or in the traffic control orders of the City.
(Res. 97-582. Passed 10-27-97.)
830.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 832
Garbage and Rubbish Collectors
832.01   License required.
832.02   License application; investigations.
832.03   Conditions for denial of license.
832.04   Bond.
832.05   Fees.
832.06   Insurance.
832.07   License expiration.
832.08   License transferability.
832.09   License revocation.
832.10   Rules.
832.11   Collection vehicles.
832.12   List of customers.
832.13   Disposal of garbage and rubbish.
832.14   Identification of containers.
832.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Garbage and refuse generally - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 46.171 et seq., 123.241 et
seq., 123.361 et seq.
   Municipal authority - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 123.301 et seq.
   Authority of Health Officer re collection and disposal - see ADM.
230.02
   Motor Carrier Safety Rules - see TRAF. Ch.
486
   Littering - see GEN. OFF.
676.05
   Noxious accumulations - see GEN. OFF.
676.07
   Registration of businesses, trades and industries - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 866
   Garbage and rubbish collection and disposal - see S.U. & P.S.
Ch. 1060
832.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of collecting or transporting garbage
or rubbish, as defined in
Chapter 1060 of the Streets, Utilities and Public Services Code, without first
obtaining a license from the City for each truck or vehicle to be so used.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.02 LICENSE APPLICATION; INVESTIGATIONS.
   (a)   Any person desiring to engage in the business of collecting or
transporting garbage or rubbish shall file an application with the City Clerk,
upon a form to be furnished by the City, for a license for each truck or
vehicle to be used in the collection or transportation of garbage or rubbish in
the City.
   (b)   Such application shall contain:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;
      (2)   The number, make, year and type of vehicle to be used;
      (3)   The proposed places of collection;
      (4)   The proposed schedules of collection; and
      (5)   Any other facts deemed necessary by the City.
   (c)   Each application shall be referred by the City Clerk to the Police
Department which shall investigate the accuracy of the statements in the
application, and to the Superintendent of Public Works for his or her written
report on the dumpsters and other equipment identified in the application. A
report shall be filed annually with the City Clerk by the Superintendent and
shall include location and number of dumpsters of each company.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86; Res. 03-115. Passed 3-3-03.)
832.03 CONDITIONS FOR DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   (a)   An application for a garbage or rubbish collection license may be
rejected for any of the following grounds:
      (1)   Misrepresentation of fact in the application;
      (2)   Previous revocation or suspension of the applicant's license for
garbage or refuse collection;
      (3)   Failure of the applicant to comply with applicable City, County,
State or Federal law;
      (4)   Receipt of an unfavorable report from the Police Department or the
Superintendent of Public Works; or
      (5)   Any other ground deemed necessary by the City Clerk for the general
health or welfare of the public.
   (b)   Any application rejected by the City Clerk pursuant to subsection (a)
hereof shall be immediately forwarded to the Mayor and Council for final
disposition. The rejected applicant shall be notified by the City Clerk of the
date and time when the Mayor and Council intend to consider the matter.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.04 BOND.
   Before any license to collect or transport garbage or rubbish is issued, the
applicant shall secure and file with the City Clerk a bond in the penal sum of
one thousand dollars ($1,000), indemnifying the City and conditioned upon the
faithful compliance by the licensee with all the provisions relating to the
collection and transportation of garbage and rubbish.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86; Res. 03-115. Passed 3-3-03.)
832.05 FEES.
   The City Clerk shall issue or renew a license to collect or transport
garbage or rubbish upon the receipt of a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
first vehicle used in the business, a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to
cover the cost of inspection for each additional vehicle to be used in the
collection or transportation of garbage or rubbish in the City, and a fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year for each container placed by the
collector. Failure to register by any business or to comply with the other
provisions of this chapter shall be deemed prima-facie evidence of a violation
of this chapter. The Superintendent of Public Works shall then remove and store
all containers not duly licensed or in violation at the D.P.S. yard, until
properly licensed by said business. The business in violation shall pay all
removal and storage costs, pursuant to the fee schedule established by the
Superintendent of Public Works, prior to the return and release of the
containers.
(Res. 91-29. Passed 1-22-91; Res. 03-115. Passed 3-3-03.)
832.06 INSURANCE.
   As a condition of the license, each garbage or rubbish collector shall
provide to the City proof of liability insurance of not less than one million
dollars ($1,000,000) for injuries, including death to any one person, and
subject to the same limit for each occurrence, and property damage insurance of
not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000).
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.07 LICENSE EXPIRATION.
   A license issued under this chapter shall expire on the second Tuesday of
May of each year, unless sooner revoked.
(Res. 91-29. Passed 1-22-91; Res. 03-115. Passed 3-3-03.)
832.08 LICENSE TRANSFERABILITY.
   No license to collect or transport garbage or rubbish shall be transferable
or assignable.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.09 LICENSE REVOCATION.
   Council may revoke any license issued under this chapter for a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter or of any rules made by the
Superintendent of Public Works, after holding a hearing for such purpose and
giving prior notice of such hearing to the affected party who shall have the
opportunity to be heard. Such notice shall inform the affected party of the
reasons for the proposed revocation.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.10 RULES.
   The Superintendent of Public Works shall make such rules governing the
operation of the business of rubbish or garbage collection and transportation,
in addition to the conditions contained in this chapter, as he or she may deem
necessary.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.11 COLLECTION VEHICLES.
   (a)   Identification. Each vehicle used to collect garbage or rubbish shall
bear a City license issued by the City Clerk.
(Res. 03-115. Passed 3-3-03.)
   (b)   Construction. All vehicles used in the collection of garbage or
rubbish shall be constructed of metal, shall be watertight and shall be kept
clean and free from odors. All such vehicles shall be kept closed and all
covers thereon shall be securely fastened while being used to transport garbage
and at all other times, except when necessary to open the covers to receive
garbage or rubbish.
   All vehicles used in the collection or transportation of garbage or rubbish
shall be of such construction and so operated that the contents thereof shall
not spill upon the streets or alleys or otherwise create a nuisance.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.12 LIST OF CUSTOMERS.
   At the time of the issuance or renewal of a license required by this
chapter, the licensee shall provide the City Clerk with a current written list
of the names and addresses of all persons in the City who have contracted with
him or her for the removal of garbage or rubbish.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.13 DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE AND RUBBISH.
   All garbage and rubbish collected by any person licensed to collect or
transport garbage and rubbish under this chapter shall be disposed of outside
the City.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.14 IDENTIFICATION OF CONTAINERS.
   Each container placed in the City by a licensee shall have visibly printed
thereon the name of the licensee.
(Res. 86-480. Passed 6-30-86.)
832.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 834
Donation Bins
834.01   Definition.
834.02   License required.
834.03   License application.
834.04   License fees.
834.05   Revocation of license.
834.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Charitable Organizations and Solicitation Act - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 400.271
et seq.
   Definition of charitable organization - see M.C.L.A. Sec. 400.272
   Charities - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 554.351 et seq.
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Registration of business, trades and industries - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 866
   Donation bins as accessory uses - see P. & Z.
1294.40
834.01 DEFINITION.
   As used in this chapter, “donation bin” shall mean a receptacle designed
with a door, slot, or other opening that is intended to accept and store
donated items; provided, however, that the definition of “donation bins” shall
not include trailers where personnel are present to accept donations.
(Res. 2017-121A. Passed 4-17-17.)
834.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall keep, install or maintain a donation bin(s) in the City
without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this chapter. This
license is in addition to the required permit as set forth in the Codified
Ordinances of the City of Lincoln Park, Michigan, Section
1294.40.
(Res. 2017-121A. Passed 4-17-17.)
834.03 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   (a)   Application for a license under this chapter shall be made at the
office of the City Clerk. Blank applications for this purpose shall be issued
by the City Clerk. The applications shall contain information as shall be
required by the City Clerk or duly authorized representative. The application
for a license shall be forwarded to the Building Department.
   (b)   An application of a license for a donation bin shall be filed with the
City Clerk and upon receipt of the required licensing fee.
(Res. 2017-121A. Passed 4-17-17.)
834.04 LICENSE FEES.
   (a)   Every applicant, before being granted a license shall pay the annual
license fee, as listed in the Lincoln Park Fee Schedule, for the privilege of
maintaining a donation bin in the City.
   (b)   Each license shall expire on the first Tuesday in May of each year.
(Res. 2017-121A. Passed 4-17-17.)
834.05 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Every license issued under this chapter is subject to the right, which is
expressly reserved, to revoke the same should the licensee, directly or
indirectly, permit the operation of any donation bin contrary to the provisions
of this chapter, the code of the city, or the laws of the state. The license
may be revoked by the City Council after written notice to the licensee, which
notice shall specify the ordinance or law violations which the licensee is
charged, and if, after a hearing, the licensee is found to be guilty of the
violations. Ten days’ notice of the hearing shall be given the licensee. At the
hearing the licensee may present evidence in his defense.
(Res. 2017-121A. Passed 4-17-17.)
834.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 836
Hawkers and Peddlers

836.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to license - see M.C.L.A. Sec. 91.1
   Hawkers and peddlers generally - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.371 et seq.
   Secondhand dealers - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.401 et seq.; B.R. & T.
Ch. 870
   Street trades by minors - see GEN. OFF.
660.06
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.

   Itinerant vendors - see B.R. & T.

   Milk and ice vending machines - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 854
   Solicitors and canvassers - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 876
836.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of hawking or peddling in the City
without first obtaining a license therefor from the City Clerk.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.02 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Before any license required by this chapter is issued, the applicant shall
file with the City Clerk a written application for such license, setting forth
the following:
   (a)   The full name, residence and business address and occupation of the
applicant at the time of filing of the application;
   (b)   The nature of the articles to be sold, offered for sale, hawked or
peddled;
   (c)   The proposed method of hawking or peddling, whether on foot or by
handcart, truck or otherwise;
   (d)   The proposed method of delivery to buyers, whether by weight, measure,
package or otherwise;
   (e)   The length of time for which the license is desired;
   (f)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant proposes to make use of
measures or scales;
   (g)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant holds a license from
any municipality other than the City, giving the number of such license if any
is held;
   (h)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant holds a license from
the State, giving the number of such license if such a license is held;
   (i)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted
of a felony or misdemeanor and, if convicted, the nature of the crime and the
date and place of conviction; and
   (j)   The affidavit of the applicant as to the truth of the application.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.03 BOND.
   Upon the filing of a license application and the sealing of the weights and
measures, if weights and measures are used, the applicant shall present to the
City Clerk, for his or her approval, a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000), with two sufficient sureties, who shall appear before the City Clerk
and justify as such sureties, if so required by the City Clerk. Such bond shall
be conditioned upon full compliance with this chapter and all ordinances of the
City and the payment of all fines, penalties and costs which may be imposed by
any court of competent jurisdiction for a violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter or any ordinance of the City. However, the City Clerk may accept a
bond from a corporation covering its employees who are licensees under this
chapter if such bond meets all of the other requirements of this section and is
in an amount equal to or in excess of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per
employee.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.04 LICENSE ISSUANCE; INVESTIGATIONS.
   Upon the filing of a license application, the sealing of the weights and
measures, if weights and measures are used, the filing of the bond and the
payment of the appropriate fee, the following procedure shall be followed
before such license shall be issued:
   (a)   The application shall be referred to the Chief of Police or his
designee who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's criminal history
and business history to be made as he or she deems necessary for the protection
of the public welfare.
   (b)   The applicant shall have all motor vehicles used in the course of
business inspected for safety and fitness by the Traffic Division of the Police
Department. Said applicant shall present a current Michigan Department of State
driver's license record with the application.
   (c)   If, as a result of the investigation, the applicant's criminal and
business history is found to be unsatisfactory, the Chief of Police shall
endorse on such application his or her disapproval and reasons for the same,
and shall return the application to the City Clerk who shall notify the
applicant that his or her application is disapproved and that no permit or
license will be issued.
   (d)   If, as a result of such investigation, the criminal and business
history of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the Chief of Police
shall endorse his or her approval on the application and shall return the
application to the City Clerk who shall issue to the applicant the prescribed
license.
(Res. 03-200A. Passed 5-5-03.)
   (e)   The City Clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued
under this chapter.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.05 LICENSE FEES.
   Before any license required by this chapter is issued, the applicant shall
pay to the City Treasurer the fee required by the following schedule:
   (a)   For peddling by foot or by handcart, two dollars ($2.00) a day for any
number of days not exceeding ten, and for any number of days exceeding ten and
not exceeding one year, twenty dollars ($20.00) for hawking and vending;
   (b)   For peddling from or with a wagon, truck or other vehicle propelled by
power, five dollars ($5.00) per year.
836.06 LIMITATIONS ON ISSUANCE OF LICENSES.
   No license required by this chapter shall be issued to any person who has
been convicted of a felony or to any person who has been convicted of any
misdemeanor pertaining to a sexual deviation or moral turpitude, except that
the Mayor and Council may order the City Clerk to issue a license when it
appears to the Mayor and Council that such applicant is presently a law abiding
citizen and that the issuance of the license is not likely to adversely affect
the health, welfare, morals or safety of the people of the City. However,
nothing contained in this section shall be interpreted to exempt the person
issued a license pursuant to this chapter from complying with all of the other
requirements of this chapter and other ordinance provisions of the City.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.07 LICENSE CARD; STICKERS.
   Upon full compliance by the applicant with the terms and conditions set
forth in Sections
836.02 through
836.06, the City Clerk shall issue to the applicant a license to engage in
business within the City under the terms and conditions of this chapter, and at
the same time the City Clerk shall issue one pocket card, of a design to be
changed each year, bearing the number of the license and the words "Peddler's
License, City of Lincoln Park," which card must at all times be carried by the
licensee while he or she is engaged in the conduct of his or her business
within the City. A sticker shall be issued to any vehicle used by the licensee
after passing inspection under Section
836.04(b), and after paying an inspection fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
Such sticker shall be prominently displayed on such vehicle.
836.08 LICENSE EXPIRATION.
   A license issued under this chapter shall expire at 12:00 midnight on the
first Tuesday in May following its issuance, unless it expires at an earlier
date under the terms thereof.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.09 LICENSE REVOCATION.
   For any violation of the conditions of any license issued under this
chapter, Council may revoke any license after a hearing given to the licensee.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.10 PEDDLING FROM FIXED LOCATIONS.
   No license required by this chapter shall be issued to any person for
peddling, hawking or vending from any stand or other device in a fixed
location. Peddling, hawking and vending from any stand or other device in a
fixed location is expressly prohibited.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.11 REGULATIONS.
   Licensees engaged in business within the City under this chapter shall
comply with the following regulations, which regulations shall be printed upon
the back of the license issued by the City Clerk:
   (a)   Every licensee, upon the request of any person to whom goods, wares or
merchandise are offered for sale, shall exhibit the license issued by the City
Clerk and permit such person to examine the same.
   (b)   Every licensee shall exhibit his or her license to any police officer,
marshal or officer of the City upon demand.
   (c)   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any article or commodity
purporting to be in a quantity of a standard weight or measure, whether or not
in the original package, unless the same is actually of the weight or measure
purported.
   (d)   No licensee shall shout or call out his or her wares in a loud,
boisterous or unseemly manner to the disturbance of the residents or dwellers
in the City, nor shall any licensee use any horn, bell or other noisemaking
device to call attention to his or her wares.
   (e)   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any unsound, unripe or
unwholesome food or defective, faulty, incomplete or deteriorated article or
merchandise. However, if the applicant for any license sets forth in his or her
application that he or she proposes to sell certain faulty or defective
merchandise for a price reduced from the usual and regular cost of the article,
such fact shall be endorsed upon his or her license, and upon exhibition of
such license to the buyer, such sale may be made if the article is other than
food or material for food.
   (f)   No licensee shall stop or remain in any one place upon the streets,
alleys or public places of the City longer than is necessary to make a sale to
a customer wishing to buy, nor shall any licensee stop or remain upon any
private property within the City without the consent of the owner thereof or
some person having authority to grant such permission.
   (g)   No licensee shall, during school hours, sell or offer for sale any
merchandise upon the streets, alleys or public places of the City contiguous or
adjacent to any property used for school purposes and within 200 feet of such
property.
   (h)   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any merchandise upon the
streets, alleys or public places within the City other than during the
following prescribed hours:
         Months            Hours
         October through January   10:00 a.m. - 6:00 p.m.
         February through March   10:00 a.m. - 7:00 p.m.
         April            10:00 a.m. - 8:00 p.m.
         May through August      10:00 a.m. - 9:00 p.m.
         September         10:00 a.m. - 8:00 p.m.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.12 GARBAGE AND RUBBISH.
   Each peddler's vehicle shall be equipped with a receptacle for the disposal
of wrappers, papers, envelopes or other containers. The peddler shall pick up
such wrappers, papers and envelopes after any sale or delivery of his or her
products.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.13 PEDDLING OF FOOD; FOODHANDLER'S CARD REQUIRED.
   No license shall be issued under this chapter to hawk or peddle food which
may be, or which customarily is, consumed by humans after the sale thereof by
the licensee without first being cooked, unless the applicant for such license
possesses a foodhandler's card issued by the authorized agency of the County.
(Ord. 87-178. Passed 3-30-87.)
836.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 840
Itinerant Vendors
840.01   Itinerant vendor defined.
840.02   Exceptions to chapter.
840.03   License required; application.
840.04   License fee.
840.05   License transferability; display.
840.06   Bond.
840.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to license - see M.C.L.A. Sec. 91.1
   Hawkers and peddlers generally - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.371 et seq.; B.R. &
T.
Ch. 836
   Secondhand dealers - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.401 et seq.; B.R. & T.
Ch. 870
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Charitable solicitations - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 812
   Solicitors and canvassers - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 876
840.01 ITINERANT VENDOR DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "itinerant vendor," means and includes all persons,
both principals and agents, who engage or conduct in the City, either in one
locality or in traveling from place to place, in a temporary or transient
business of selling goods, wares and merchandise with the intention of
continuing in the business in one place for not more than 120 days, and who,
for the purpose of carrying on such business, use, lease or occupy, either in
whole or in part, a room, building or other structure for the exhibition and
sale of such goods, wares and merchandise.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.52.010)
840.02 EXCEPTIONS TO CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall not apply to sales made to dealers by commercial
travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business, for resale; nor to
bona fide sales of goods, wares or merchandise for future delivery; nor to
hawkers on the streets or peddlers from vehicles; nor to the sale of goods,
wares or merchandise during the continuance of any annual fair; nor to sales by
societies acting for charitable, religious or public purposes.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.52.020)
840.03 LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   (a)   Every itinerant vendor desiring to do business in the City shall make
an application in writing to the City Clerk for a license to operate as an
itinerant vendor, which application shall be filed with the City Clerk at least
seven days before the applicant is authorized to begin the business.
   (b)   The application shall contain a statement under oath containing all
facts relating to the reasons for the character of the business which the
applicant desires to transact, including a true statement of the names and
addresses of persons from whom the goods, wares or merchandise were last taken;
the name and address of the owner or person in whose interest such business is
conducted; the places and dates where the applicant, for the past eighteen
months, has been engaged in business, stating the nature and character of the
business; and all details necessary to exactly locate and fully identify all
goods, wares or merchandise to be sold, and the length of time for which the
store or place where the goods, wares or merchandise are to be sold has been or
is to be leased.
   (c)   The fact that such store or place of business has been or is to be
leased for less than 120 days shall be in all cases prima-facie evidence that
the business is of a temporary or transient character within the meaning of
this chapter.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.52.030)
840.04 LICENSE FEE.
   A license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each week or fraction thereof
during which an itinerant vendor desires to sell his or her goods shall be paid
by the itinerant vendor prior to the issuance of a license.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.52.040)
840.05 LICENSE TRANSFERABILITY; DISPLAY.
   No person shall conduct the business of itinerant vendor without first
securing a license for each place to be operated. No such license shall be
transferable, nor shall it be used by any person other than as named in the
license. The licensee shall conspicuously display the license in his or her
place of business so that the same is plainly visible to the public.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.52.050)
840.06 BOND.
   Before a license as provided in this chapter is issued, the applicant shall
execute and deliver to the City Clerk a good and sufficient bond in the sum of
one thousand dollars ($1,000) with good and sufficient surety, to be approved
by the City Clerk as to sufficiency of surety and by the City Attorney as to
form. Such bond shall be conditioned as to indemnify or reimburse any purchaser
of goods, wares or merchandise in a sum equal to at least the amount of any
payment such purchaser may have been induced to make through misrepresentation
as to the kind, quality or value of such goods, wares or merchandise, whether
the misrepresentations were made by the owner or by his or her servants, agents
or employees either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement
of any character whatsoever printed or circulated with reference to the stock
of goods, wares and merchandise, or any part thereof. Such bond shall be
further conditioned for the faithful performance of all the provisions of this
chapter.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.52.060)
840.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 842
Junk Dealers
842.01   License required.
842.02   License application; issuance; bond.
842.03   License term; conditions for issuance.
842.04   License fees.
842.05   Suspension or revocation of licenses.
842.06   Location restrictions; fences.
842.07   Pawning prohibited.
842.08   Records.
842.09   Storage; barriers or curbs.
842.10   Hours of operation; general restrictions.
842.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Secondhand dealers - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.401 et seq.; B.R. & T.
Ch. 870
   Junk yards - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.451 et seq.
   Pawnbrokers - see M.C.L.A. Secs. 445.471 et seq.,
446.201 et seq.; B.R. & T.
Ch. 862
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Registration of businesses, trades and industries - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 866
   Used auto parts - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 886
842.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of a junk dealer for the purchase or
sale of what is commonly called junk, such as rags, paper, bags, bagging, iron,
brass, copper, tin, zinc, aluminum, scrap or discarded metal, bottles or other
articles, whether manufactured or in the process of manufacture of such
material, and whether old or new, and no person shall transport through the
streets or alleys of the City any conveyance for the purpose of collecting or
disposing of such articles, without first obtaining a license therefor from the
City Clerk as provided in this chapter.
842.02 LICENSE APPLICATION; ISSUANCE; BOND.
   The City Clerk is hereby authorized to grant a license to any reputable
person who is a citizen of the United States, or to any partnership or
corporation, to engage in the business of a junk dealer, for the purchase and
sale of articles mentioned in Section
842.01, upon filing an application therefor and paying into the City treasury a
license fee as set forth in Section
842.04, and upon executing a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000), with one or more sureties to be approved by the City Clerk,
conditioned that he or she will faithfully observe the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 87-176. Passed 3-30-87.)
842.03 LICENSE TERM; CONDITIONS FOR ISSUANCE.
   The City Clerk may refuse to issue a license to any applicant who has been
previously convicted of any crime or who has been twice convicted of a
violation of this chapter, or for other good cause shown. Every license issued
under this chapter shall expire one year after the date of issuance. Each
application for a license shall contain an agreement on the part of the
applicant that he or she will accept the license, if granted to him or her,
upon the condition that it may be suspended or revoked at the will of the City
Clerk. Any license issued under Section
842.02 shall state the street number or location of the office or yard
designated in the application as constituting the principal place of business
of the licensee. No person shall use such license for any other location
without first obtaining the approval of the City Clerk, in writing.
842.04 LICENSE FEES.
   The fees for a license issued under this chapter shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per year for any yard, lot, building or establishment and ten
dollars ($10.00) for each wagon or truck used by a licensee in his or her
business.
842.05 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES.
   (a)   The City Clerk may, at any time, suspend or revoke any license granted
under this chapter and order the shop or place of business to be closed. All
licenses granted under this chapter are issued and accepted with the
understanding that they are subject to suspension or revocation. The Chief of
Police shall cause to be served upon the holder of the license so suspended or
revoked, or upon the person in charge of the business, notice, in writing, of
such action by the City Clerk. No person shall continue to operate such
business after the service upon him or her of such notice of suspension or
revocation.
   (b)   Before such license is suspended or revoked by the City Clerk,
charges, in writing, shall be served upon such licensee. He or she shall be
given a hearing before the City Clerk, with a reasonable opportunity to present
evidence in his or her defense, with or without the benefit of counsel, as he
or she desires. If a licensee feels aggrieved by the finding and/or action of
the City Clerk at the hearing, he or she may appeal the cause to Council where
such charges and defense may be heard de novo. After such hearing Council shall
make a finding and determination which shall be final and binding upon the
licensee and the City.
842.06 LOCATION RESTRICTIONS; FENCES.
   No building, place or lot for junk, rags, old rope, paper, bagging, old
iron, brass, copper, tin, bottles, salvage parts of old automobiles, old
lumber, house wrecking material, slush, lead or like articles shall be
established in the City unless the owner, operator or person in control, prior
to such establishment, secures permission to establish the same. Such
permission shall be granted by resolution of Council. In no event shall any
such building, place or lot be so established where sixty-five percent or more
of the property owners within a radius of one City block of such premises
object, in writing, to the establishment of the same. No junk shall be stored
or kept on any open lot or space, unless the licensee, or someone in his or her
behalf, erects a tight-board fence eight feet high surrounding the same, which
fence shall be painted and kept properly maintained.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.68.070)
842.07 PAWNING PROHIBITED.
   No licensee under this chapter shall receive, in the course of his or her
business, any article by way of a pledge or pawn, nor shall he or she loan or
advance any sum of money on the security of any article or thing.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.68.080)
842.08 RECORDS.
   Every licensee under this chapter shall, on demand, exhibit all goods bought
or received, and give the name, address and description of the person from whom
the same was purchased or received, to the City Clerk or any police officer of
the City. The licensee shall keep a record or book, written in ink in the
English language, containing the names, residences and descriptions of all
persons from whom goods are purchased or received.
842.09 STORAGE; BARRIERS OR CURBS.
   All articles purchased or received in exchange by any party licensed under
this chapter shall be retained by him or her, for at least fifteen days before
disposing of them, in an accessible place in the building or yard. Such
building or yard shall be graded and properly illuminated at all times. In
cases of open lots, automobiles shall not be parked closer than two feet from
the lot line wherever the lot abuts a public sidewalk, and one foot from other
lot lines of the lot. A barrier eighteen inches high and two feet from all
public sidewalk lines and parallel thereto shall be constructed and maintained
except in front of the area used for entrances and exits to the lot. In lieu of
the barrier, a curb may be constructed, extending six inches above the ground
surface and set back from the sidewalk a sufficient distance to keep all motor
vehicles on the lot at least two feet from all public sidewalks.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.68.100)
842.10 HOURS OF OPERATION; GENERAL RESTRICTIONS.
   No licensee shall purchase or receive, by sale, barter, exchange, gift or
otherwise, any article mentioned in this chapter from any person between 7:00
p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following day; from any person under seventeen years
of age; from any person who is at the time intoxicated; from a habitual
drunkard; from any person who is at the time under the influence of drugs; from
a habitual drug addict; from any person known by such licensee to be a thief,
an associate of thieves or a receiver of stolen property; or from any person he
or she has reason to suspect of being such. No minor under seventeen years of
age shall be permitted to loiter about the premises of any licensee, or ride
upon the licensee's vehicle or accompany any licensee in the collection of
junk. No person shall be permitted upon the premises of such licensee between
7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following day, except the necessary watchman;
and except that a licensee may, with his or her family, dwell upon the premises
where his or her business is located, provided that he or she shall not conduct
such business or receive, buy or sell junk between 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of
the following day.
(1979 Code Sec. 5.68.110)
842.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 844
Kiddie Lands and Kiddie Rides
844.01   Definitions.
844.02   License required; suspension authority.
