   (i)   General Layout And Design Standards.
      (1)   Landscaped areas and plant materials required by this Zoning Code
shall be kept free from refuse and debris. Plant materials, including lawns,
shall be maintained in a healthy growing condition, neat and orderly in
appearance. If any plant material required by this Zoning Code dies or becomes
diseased, it shall be replaced within thirty (30) days of written notice from
the City or within an extended time period as specified in said notice.
      (2)   Tree stakes, guy wires and tree wrap are to be removed after one
(1) year.
      (3)   All landscaped areas shall be provided with a readily available and
acceptable water supply, or with at least one (1) outlet located within one-
hundred (100) feet of all planted material to be maintained. Frontage
landscaping, boulevard medians, interior parking lot landscaped areas, and
other curbed landscaped areas shall be irrigated via an underground sprinkler
system.
      (4)   Landscaping materials and arrangement shall ensure adequate sight
visibility for motorists, adequate clearance for pedestrians and vehicles, and
accessibility to fire hydrants.
      (5)   Cul-de-sacs, site entrances and boulevard medians shall be
landscaped with species tolerant of roadside conditions in southeast Michigan.
      (6)   Landscaping within the site shall be approved in consideration of
sight distance, size of planting area, location of sidewalks, maintenance of
adequate overhead clearance, accessibility to fire hydrants, visibility to
approved signs of adjacent uses, compatibility with the visual character of the
surrounding area, maintenance-performance guarantee, and curbing around
landscape areas.
      (7)   Plantings within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant shall be no
taller than six (6) inches at maturity.
   (j)   Incentives to Preserve Existing Trees. The City encourages the
preservation of quality and mature trees by providing credits toward the
required trees for greenbelts, buffer strips, interior landscaping, and within
parking lots. Trees intended to be preserved shall be indicated with a special
symbol on the site plan and be protected during construction through use of a
fence around the drip line. Tree species, location, and caliper must be shown
on the landscape plan. Tree protection measures must be shown and noted on the
landscape plan. To obtain credit, the preserved trees shall be of a high
quality and at least two and one-half (2 ½) inches caliper. Trees to be
preserved shall be counted for credit only if they are located on the developed
portion of the site as determined by the Planning Commission. Trees over twelve
(12) inches in caliper to be removed shall be noted on the landscape plan.
   The credit for preserved trees shall be as follows. Any preserved trees
receiving credit which are lost within two (2) years after construction shall
be replaced by the land owner with trees otherwise required.
 
Caliper of Preserved Tree (in inches) Numbers of Trees Credited
over 12                               3
8 to 12                               2
2 ½ to 8                             1
 
Note: Caliper measurement for existing trees is the diameter at a height of
four and one-half (4.5) feet above the natural grade. (Diameter at Breast
Height - D.B.H.)
   The following trees are not eligible for preservation credits:
   Box Elder   Apple   Poplar
   Willow   Hawthorn   Malus (sp.)
   Hackberry   Silver Maple   European Alder
   Locust (sp.)   Autumn Olive   Norway Maple
   Scotch Pine   Buckthorn   Siberian Elm
   Red Pine
   (k)   Waiver or Modification of Standards for Special Situations. The
Planning Commission may determine whether or not existing landscaping or
screening intended to be preserved, or a different landscape design, would
provide all or part of the required landscaping and screening. In making such a
determination to waive or reduce the landscaping and screening requirements of
this section, the following may be considered:
      (1)   The extent that existing natural vegetation provides desired
screening.
      (2)   Whether there is a steep change in topography which would limit the
benefits of required landscaping.
      (3)   The presence of existing wetlands and watercourses.
      (4)   Existing and proposed building placement.
      (5)   Whether the abutting or adjacent land is developed or planned by
the City for a use other than residential uses.
      (6)   Building heights and views.
      (7)   Whether the adjacent Residential District is over two-hundred (200)
feet away from the subject site.
      (8)   Whether similar conditions to the above exist such that no good
purpose would be served by providing the landscaping or screening required.
   (l)   Entranceway Structures. Entranceway structures, such as walls,
columns, or gates shall be permitted at the entrance to a residential or
nonresidential subdivision or condominium development, industrial park, or
business park, subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   Entranceway structures shall be located on private property outside
of the road right-of-way, except that such structures may be located in the
median of a boulevard entrance to a subdivision or other residential
development (in the road right-of-way), subject to approval by the entity
having jurisdiction over the right-of-way (i.e. Wayne County, Lincoln Park,
MDOT, etc.) and subject to compliance with the Unobstructed Sight Distance
standards in Section
1290.08. Entranceway structures located on private property may be within the
required front setback area.
      (2)   Entranceway structures shall not exceed eight (8) feet in height
and eighty (80) square feet in size.
      (3)   Approval of the Building Official and issuance of a building permit
shall be required prior to construction.
(Res. 10-67A. Passed 4-19-10. Eff. 5-5-10.)
1296.04 STANDARDS FOR ARCHITECTURE AND BUILDING MATERIALS.
   (a)   Purpose and Intent. The purpose of the following architectural and
site design standards is to evaluate proposed buildings and site improvements
during site plan review to ensure that certain design and appearance standards
are maintained. These standards provide a means of evaluating whether the
proposed building design and site layout meet the overall intent of site plan
review, the Comprehensive Development Plan, and this Zoning Code. These
standards also are intended to protect the general health, safety, and welfare
of the City by ensuring that the City’s property values, building designs,
appearance, character, and natural resources are preserved and respected by
achieving high quality design and adding distinctive architectural features and
roof lines to the viewscapes of the City, while providing for architectural
creativity.
   (b)   Architectural Standards. All proposals requiring site plan review and
fronting on a public right-of-way shall meet or exceed the following standards
for architecture and building materials.
      (1)   Building form. For sites where setbacks are required and buildings
are not permitted to be built to lot lines, building mass, height, bulk and
width-to-height ratio must be within fifty percent (50%) to one-hundred-fifty
percent (150%) of the scale and proportion of buildings within five-hundred
(500) feet of the subject site, unless meeting such ratio is determined to be
impractical or unreasonable by the Planning Commission.
         A.   An uninterrupted length of a single building facade shall not
exceed one- hundred (100) feet for all buildings. Recesses, off-sets, angular
forms, or other features shall be used to provide a changing and varying
facade.
         B.   Windows shall be vertical, recessed and include visually-obvious
sills. Spaces between windows shall be formed by columns, mullions, or material
found elsewhere on the facade. Solid walls of glass are not permitted.
         C.   Main entrances shall be emphasized with doors larger than
required by the applicable building code(s) and framing devices such as deep
overhangs, recesses, peaked roof forms, porches, or arches.
      (2)   Architectural details and features. Buildings shall possess
architectural variety, but shall be constructed of similar, but not identical,
materials, and shall have similar, but not identical, entrances, to those
buildings within five-hundred (500) feet of the subject site, unless the
Planning Commission determines other building materials and forms are
acceptable.
         A.   Pitched and shingled roof forms with overhanging eaves between
six (6) inches of vertical rise to twelve (12) inches of horizontal run and
twelve (12) inches of vertical rise to twelve (12) inches of horizontal run are
recommended. Distinctively shaped roof forms, detailed parapets, and
exaggerated cornice lines should be incorporated into roof lines along building
facades greater than one-hundred (100) feet. Roof-top mechanical equipment must
be screened by the roof form.
         B.   Building facades greater than one-hundred (100) feet shall
contain architectural features, details and ornaments such as arches,
colonnades, columns, pilasters, detailed trim, brick bands, contrasting courses
of material, cornices or porches. All sides of a building shall be similar in
design, details, and materials.
         C.   Main entrances to buildings shall incorporate devices such as
canopies, overhangs, raised parapets over the door, archways, awnings, larger
door openings and display windows, accent colors, and details such as tile
work, moldings, pedestrian-scale lighting, and distinctive door pulls.
         D.   Natural colors shall be used for the main portions of building
facades and roof forms. Bright or fluorescent colors are permitted for trim,
accent, and other decorative architectural features only.
      (3)   Building materials. Building materials must be primarily natural
products, conveying permanence, such as brick, decorative masonry block, stone,
or beveled wood siding, and each building facade must contain at least seventy-
five percent (75%) of these materials. Uses in Industrial Districts shall
contain at least fifty percent (50%) of these materials for building facades
facing public streets or freeways.
      Twenty-five percent (25%) of building facades may contain the following
materials, which should be used for decorative features or accents only: glass,
unless used as windows; reflective glass; exterior insulation finish systems
(EIFS); vinyl, aluminum, or steel siding; or similar synthetic or highly-
reflective materials. Building facades for uses in industrial districts not
facing public streets or freeways may also contain these materials and pre-cast
concrete or plain masonry block.
      (4)   Windows. Front facades shall include at least twenty-five percent
(25%) windows. The approximate size, shape, orientation and spacing of windows
should match that of buildings within five-hundred (500) feet, unless the
Planning Commission determines other sizes, shapes, orientation, and spacing
are acceptable.

1400.01 LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS.
   It is the intent of the Mayor and Council to decriminalize offenses
generally known as building code violations as codified in Part Fourteen of the
Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 04-67A. Passed 3-1-04.)
1400.02 PENALTY AND SANCTION; MUNICIPAL CIVIL INFRACTION.
   Violations of the provisions in this chapter and all provisions of Part
Fourteen are Municipal Civil Infractions and subject to the penalty and
sanctions described in Section
202.101. The imposition of the penalty and sanctions provided in Section
202.101 shall not preclude the initiation of appropriate legal action to
restrain, correct, or abate a violation, to prevent illegal occupancy of a
rental dwelling or dwelling unit or to stop an illegal act, conduct of a
business or use of a structure.
(Ord. 04-67A. Passed 3-1-04.)

1410.01 ADOPTION BY REFERENCE.
   Pursuant to the provisions of Section 3(k) of Act 270 of 1909, State of
Michigan, as amended, Michigan Compiled Laws 117.3(k) and Section 8a of Act 230
of 1972, State of Michigan, as amended, Michigan Compiled Laws 125.1508a, the
State of Michigan Building Code is hereby adopted by reference by the City of
Lincoln Park for the purpose of regulating the erection, construction,
alteration, addition, repair, removal, demolition, use, location, occupancy and
maintenance of all buildings and structures, and shall apply to existing or
proposed buildings and structures in the City of Lincoln Park. A complete copy
of the code is available for inspection in the Lincoln Park Building
Department.
(Res. 08-316A. Passed 10-6-08.)
1410.02 ENFORCEMENT BY MANAGER OF THE BUILDING AND ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT.
   Pursuant to the provisions of the Michigan Building, Electrical, Mechanical
and Plumbing Codes, in accordance with Act 230 of the Public Acts of 1972, as
amended, the Building Official (Manager of the Building & Engineering
Department) of the City of Lincoln Park is hereby designated as the official of
the enforcing agency authorized to discharge the responsibility of the City of
Lincoln Park under Act 230 of the Public Acts of 1972, State of Michigan. The
City of Lincoln Park assumes responsibility for the administration and
enforcement of said Act throughout its corporate limits.
(Res. 08-316A. Passed 10-6-08.)
1410.03 ESTABLISHMENT OF FEES.
   All fees charged by the City of Lincoln Park for applications for permits,
examination of plans, issuance of permits, inspections of construction,
issuance of certificates of use and occupancy, inspection of premises, issuance
of certificates of compliance, registration of licenses and contractors,
applications for hearings or review by any board or commission, and other
services required and performed by the City of Lincoln Park or any of its
officers or employees shall be as established from time to time by resolution
of the City Council.
(Res. 08-316A. Passed 10-6-08.)

1414.02
1420.01 MANAGER OF THE BUILDING AND ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   Establishment of Office. The office of Manager of the Building and
Engineering Department is hereby established pursuant to
Chapter IV of the City Charter.
   (b)   Appointment; Term of Office. The Manager shall be appointed by Mayor
and Council and shall hold office as such for a term to expire on the first
Monday in January of odd-numbered years.
   (c)   Qualifications; Combination of Offices.
      (1)   The Manager shall be a state-licensed code official and possess all
of the qualifications required by City Charter and State Law.
      (2)   The Manager shall have a minimum of two years background and
experience in the building trades prior to appointment. Although practical,
hands-on experience shall be important, it is ideal that the Manager be
licensed in one or more of the building trades or in drafting and reading
blueprints, and have prior managerial experience, to administer and manage the
many facets of the Building and Engineering Department.
      (3)   Council may combine the duties of the Manager with those of any
other appointive office established by the City Charter or by ordinance and may
appoint one City officer to perform the duties of the combined offices.
   (d)   Duties.
      (1)   The Manager shall supervise and control the activities of the
Building Department and its personnel, which personnel shall include, but not
be limited to, the Electrical Inspector, the Plumbing Inspector and the Heating
and Refrigeration Inspector.
      (2)   The Manager of the Building and Engineering Department shall report
to and be subject to the general direction of the City Manager. He or she shall
issue building permits and enforce and perform the duties of the Building
Inspector in the absence of a Building Inspector or Assistant Building
Inspector. He or she, or his or her duly authorized representative or designee,
shall ensure the performance of those department activities required to
implement the City’s urban renewal and/or code enforcement programs. He or she
shall perform such other duties as are assigned to him or her from time to time
by the Mayor and Council.
(Res. 07-54A. Passed 2-12-07; Res. 08-317A. Passed 10-6-08; Res. 2021-148A.
Passed 5-17-21.)

1420.03 PLUMBING INSPECTOR.
   (a)   The office of Plumbing Inspector, heretofore established, the duties
of which shall be under the supervision of the Superintendent of the Building
Department, is hereby retained.
   (b)   The compensation for the Plumbing Inspector shall be sixty-five
percent of the permit fees collected by the City for inspections. The balance
of such permit fees shall be retained by the City. He or she shall also receive
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each appearance in court on behalf of the
City.
   (c)   The Plumbing Inspector shall receive no other compensation and no
fringe benefits, except that he or she shall receive sixty-five percent of the
equivalent of the permit fee in City inspections in those cases where no permit
fee is actually paid.

   (a)   Establishment of Position. There is hereby established in and for the

Chapter IV of the City Charter.
(Res. 82-666. Passed 7-19-82; Res. 86-59. Passed 1-14-86.)
   (b)   Compensation. The Plan Reviewer shall receive such salary as
determined from time to time by Council. The Plan Reviewer shall receive
retirement benefits, but shall receive no other fringe benefits.
   Such salary shall be paid in equal payments on the regular pay days
established for classified employees.
(Adopting Ordinance)
   (c)   Duties. The duties of the Plan Reviewer shall include, but not be
limited to:
      (1)   Providing a systematic analysis of proposed developments in light
of requirements prescribed by the Zoning Code for specific occupancies in
specific zoning districts;
      (2)   Checking the legal description of property as supplied by the
applicant;
      (3)   Performing field checks of proposed sites to ensure compatibility
with existing structures;
      (4)   Checking all aspects of developments to ensure compliance with
Section
1290.29 of the Zoning Code;
      (5)   Submitting written reports and recommendations to the Planning
Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals; and
      (6)   Performing such other duties as may be required by the Mayor, or
the Mayor and Council, and submitting such reports as may be required by the
Mayor or the Mayor and Council.
(Res. 82-666. Passed 7-19-82; Res. 86-130. Passed 2-10-86.)

1428.01 PAYMENT.
   The fees set forth in this chapter shall be payable to the City Treasurer
prior to any site plan review, any construction plan examination and the
issuance of a permit or license.
(Res. 86-611. Passed 9-2-86.)
1428.02 SITE PLAN REVIEW.
   Prior to the erection of any building or structure, or any addition or
alteration thereto, in any zoning district of the City, and prior to the
commencement of any land use requiring special approval or any planned unit
development, other than single-family detached residences and accessory
buildings, twelve sets of site plans shall be submitted to the Building
Department as set forth in Section
1290.29 of the Zoning Code. Fees for site plan review are as follows:
   (a)   Nonresidential site plans, twenty-five dollars ($25.00) plus five
dollars ($5.00) per acre or fraction thereof;
   (b)   Residential site plans (apartments, townhouses, etc.), twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) plus two dollars ($2.00) per dwelling unit.
(Res. 86-611. Passed 9-2-86.)
1428.03 CONSTRUCTION PLAN EXAMINATIONS.
   (a)   For new residential and commercial buildings, and for additions or
alterations to existing structures, the applicant shall submit three complete
sets of structural, mechanical, electrical and plumbing plans, sealed when
required by State law, for determination of compliance with all applicable
codes and ordinances. The plan examination fee shall be paid at the time of
submission of plans for review and shall be paid in addition to any permit
fees.
   (b)   Commercial fees shall be based upon the area of new construction,
addition or alteration as follows:
         Area (sq. ft.)         Examination Fee
         Up to 2,000         $ 50.00
         2,001 to 4,000         75.00
         4,001 to 6,000         100.00
         6,001 to 8,000         125.00
         8,001 to 10,000      150.00
         10,001 to 20,000      175.00
         Over 20,000         200.00 plus $25.00 per 10,000 square feet or
fraction thereof over 20,000.
   The fee for mechanical, plumbing and electrical plan examinations shall be
five percent of the building plan examination fee.
   The fee for reviews of alterations, remodeling and submissions where no
square footage calculations are available shall be thirty-five dollars ($35.00)
per hour, with a one-hour minimum.
   (c)   Residential fees shall be as follows:
         New single-family homes      $30.00
         New two-family homes      45.00
         New multiple dwellings      30.00 first unit, $5.00 each additional
unit
         Additions or alterations      1.00 for each $1,000 of construction
cost of the proposed work with a minimum of $5.00 and a maximum of $25.00. No
fee shall be assessed for work valued below $5,000.
(Res. 86-611. Passed 9-2-86.)

cost or fraction thereof
   More than $500,000               3,500.00 plus $5.00 for each additional
$1,000 of cost or fraction thereof
(Res. 86-611. Passed 9-2-86.)

   Above-ground      $25.00

1428.09 MOVING OF BUILDINGS.
   (a)   The fee for a permit for moving a building or structure in, within or
through the City shall be as set forth in this subsection. For the moving of a
building or structure from its location on a parcel of land to some other
location, with or without passing over or going upon a public street or way,
the fee shall be as follows:
   Structure moved 1/4 mile or under               $150.00
   Over 1/4 mile                        150.00   plus $50.00 per each
additional 1/4 mile
   (b)   Prior to the issuance of a moving permit by the Building Department,
approval of the date, time schedule, route and destination must be obtained
from the Department of Public Works and Public Services, the County or State
Signal Bureau, the Traffic Safety Division, the City Engineer and the Fire
Marshal's office. A deposit of five thousand dollars ($5,000) must be paid to
the City Treasurer as a cash bond to cover any damage to public property on or
along the route incurred as a result of the moving operation.
(Res. 86-611. Passed 9-2-86.)

1428.11 ANNUAL MAINTENANCE PERMITS.

(Res. 86-611. Passed 9-2-86.)

1428.13 SIDEWALKS; DRIVEWAY APPROACHES; CURB CUTS; PRIVATE DRIVEWAYS.
   The fees for each permit for the installation, repair or cutting of
sidewalks, driveway approaches, private driveways and/or curb cuts shall be as
follows:
   Sidewalks
      Minimum fee, two flags or less         8.00
      Each additional flag or portion thereof      1.00
   Drive approaches, single drive            8.00
   Drive approaches over 8 feet               8.00 plus $1.00 per foot
   Private driveways (based on new construction
         and alteration fee schedule,
         Section 1428.04)
   Curb cuts (per linear foot)               1.00
   Minimum fee for any one curb cut            10.00
(Res. 86-611. Passed 9-2-86.)
1428.14 BOND; INSURANCE.
   Whenever a bond or policy of insurance is called for as a condition
precedent to the granting of any permit required by this Building and Housing
Code, when not otherwise expressly provided, such bond or policy of insurance
shall be in the sum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) or such larger
sum as the Superintendent of the Building Department shall specify as
commensurate with the risk to the permit applicant and the City arising out of
any injury to or death of members of the public or any property damage caused
to any member of the public or the City, which injury or damage might be
suffered through the negligent or wanton exercise of the privilege granted
under such permit. If a bond is furnished, it shall be conditioned to save
harmless the City from any loss whatsoever resulting from the doing of the
thing or the exercise of the privilege for which the permit is required. If a
policy of insurance is furnished, it shall insure the permit applicant and the
City against any loss resulting from the personal injury, death or property
damage, which loss is caused by the doing of the thing or the exercise of the
privilege for which the permit is required.
1428.15 ELECTRICAL PERMIT FEES.
   Fees for the installation of electrical equipment shall be as set from time
to time by resolution of the Mayor and Council.
(Res. 94-406. Passed 7-5-94.)
1428.16 MECHANICAL PERMIT FEES.
   Fees for the installation of mechanical equipment shall be as set from time
to time by resolution of the Mayor and Council.
(Res. 92-686. Passed 10-26-92.)
1428.17 PLUMBING PERMIT FEES.
   Fees for the installation of plumbing equipment shall be as set from time to
time by resolution of the Mayor and Council.
(Res. 94-407. Passed 7-5-94.)
CHAPTER 1430
Registration of Building Contractors

   Building Inspector - see CHTR.

1430.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Commission" means the Builder's Registration Commission of the City,
as established in Section
1430.04.
   (b)   "Registrant" means any person registered under this chapter.
   (c)   "Residential builder" means any person engaged in the construction of
residential structures or a combination of residential and commercial
structures who, for a fixed sum, price, fee, percentage, valuable consideration
or other compensation, other than wages, undertakes, offers to undertake or
purports to have the capacity to undertake with another for the erection,
construction, replacement, repair, alteration, improvement, movement, wrecking
or demolition of, or any addition to or subtraction from, a residential
structure or a combination of residential and commercial structures, or any
person who erects a residential structure or a combination of residential and
commercial structures, except for his or her own use and occupancy on his or
her own property, and who is licensed as such by the State Department of
Licensing and Regulation pursuant to Act 299 of the Public Acts of 1980, as
amended (M.C.L.A. 339.101 et seq.).
   (d)   "Residential maintenance and alteration contractor" means any person
who, for a fixed sum, price, fee, percentage, valuable consideration or other
compensation, other than wages, undertakes with another for the repair,
alteration, improvement, movement, wrecking or demolition of, or for any
addition to or subtraction from, a residential structure or a combination of
residential and commercial structures, or for the building of a garage,
excavation and sewer installation or laying of concrete on residential
property, except for his or her own use and occupancy. Whenever such contractor
is required to be licensed as such by the State Department of Licensing and
Regulation pursuant to Act 299 of the Public Acts of 1980, as amended, he or
she shall provide such registration number in his or her application.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.010)
1430.02 REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE AND STATE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   In order to safeguard and protect homeowners and persons undertaking
to become homeowners, no person shall engage in the business of or act in the
capacity of a residential builder and/or residential maintenance and alteration
contractor in the City without first obtaining a registration certificate
therefor from the Building Department.
   (b)   No building registration certificate shall be issued to any person
unless such person is licensed as a residential builder and/or residential
maintenance and alteration contractor by the State Department of Licensing and
Regulation.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.020)
1430.03 EXCEPTIONS TO CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall not apply to:
   (a)   An authorized representative of the United States government, the
State or any county, township, city, village or other political subdivision of
the State;
   (b)   Owners of property, with reference to structures thereon for their own
use and occupancy;
   (c)   Officers of a court acting within the scope of their office;
   (d)   Any person who engages or is engaged solely in the business of
performing work and services under contract with a residential builder or a
residential maintenance and alteration contractor licensed under this chapter;
or
   (e)   The sale of any products or materials, or the sale or installation of
articles of merchandise, which are not actually fabricated into and do not
become a permanent fixed part of the structure.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.030)
1430.04 BUILDERS REGISTRATION COMMISSION.
   There is hereby established in and for the City a Builders Registration
Commission. The Commission shall consist of the Superintendent of the Building
Department, who shall serve as Chairperson, the City Engineer and the president
of the Hearing Board on Dangerous Buildings and Code Appeals. The Commission
shall administer the provisions of Sections
1430.08 through
1430.11.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.040)
1430.05 CERTIFICATE APPLICATION.
   Applicants for registration under this chapter shall file a written sworn
application on forms furnished by the Building Department. Such application
shall be signed by the applicant, if an individual; by all partners, if a
partnership; by all associates, if an association; and by the president, if a
corporation. Such application shall be filed with the Department and shall
provide the following information:
   (a)   The full name and permanent address of the applicant, both business
and residence;
   (b)   The period of time, if any, during which the applicant has been
engaged in the business;
   (c)   A description of the type of business entity, i.e. corporation,
partnership or sole proprietorship;
   (d)   Names, home addresses and titles of all corporation officers, partners
or sole owners;
   (e)   The applicant's State Department of Licensing and Regulation license,
from which a copy may be made for the Builders Registration Commission's
records. If the applicant has applied to the State for his or her license but
has not yet received the same, the applicant may obtain a certificate under
this chapter on the condition that the license be obtained within 120 days.
   Such other information as to the identity or character of the applicant, or
of any of the officers or members of any such applicant, as the Building
Inspector may deem proper to fulfill the purposes of this chapter in the
protection of the public good.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.050)
1430.06 ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES.
   (a)   The Superintendent of the Building Department, upon proper
application, may issue a residential builder's registration certificate to any
applicant who qualifies therefor. Such certificate shall authorize the
registrant to engage in the business of or to act in the capacity of a
residential builder in the City. The Superintendent may issue a residential
maintenance and alteration contractor's certificate to any applicant who
qualifies therefor, according to his or her qualifications, with respect to any
of the following crafts or trades:
      (1)   Asphalt paving;
      (2)   Awnings;
      (3)   Carpentry;
      (4)   Concrete work;
      (5)   Excavation and sewer installation;
      (6)   Fences;
      (7)   Floor laying;
      (8)   Garage building;
      (9)   Insulation work;
      (10)   Lathing;
      (11)   Masonry work;
      (12)   Plastering;
      (13)   Roofing and siding;
      (14)   Sheet metal work;
      (15)   Swimming pools; and
      (16)   Tile and marble work.
   (b)   Such registration certificate, when issued, shall specify the
particular crafts and trades for which the registrant has qualified. The
Builders Registration Commission shall not require any applicant to pay more
than one registration fee regardless of the number of crafts and trades for
which he or she is registered. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit
a specialty contractor from taking and executing a contract involving the use
of two or more crafts if the performance of the work in the crafts or trades,
other than in which he or she is registered, is incidental and supplemental to
the performance of work in the craft for which the specialty contractor is
registered.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.060)
1430.07 CERTIFICATE FEE; EXPIRATION; RENEWALS.
   (a)   The registration fee for a residential builder's or residential
maintenance and alteration contractor's certificate shall be thirty dollars
($30.00), which sum shall be payable to the City Treasurer.
   (b)   Each certificate shall be issued for one year. All certificates shall
be renewable on June 1 of each year. All applications for renewals of
certificates must be made in proper form, accompanied with the proper fee,
before the date of expiration. Proper submission of the renewal application
shall automatically grant the applicant permission to operate pending the
actual issuance or refusal of renewal certificates.
   (c)   Every registrant shall report to the Superintendent of the Building
Department all changes of members and addresses of persons registered under
this chapter within thirty days after such changes occur.
(Res. 87-727. Passed 12-21-87.)
1430.08 CONDITIONS FOR SUSPENSION, REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF CERTIFICATES.
   (a)   The Builders Registration Commission may, upon its motion or upon the
written verified complaint, in writing, of any person, investigate the actions
of any residential builder, any residential maintenance and alteration
contractor or any person who assumes to act in such capacity in the City, and
may refuse to issue or renew, or may suspend or revoke, any certificate issued
under this chapter at any time and shall give written notification thereof and
the reasons therefor to the Mayor and Council.
   (b)   The following causes shall be grounds upon which the Commission may
refuse to issue or renew, or suspend or revoke, any certificate issued under
this chapter:
      (1)   Suspension or revocation of a registrant's residential builder's or
residential maintenance and alteration contractor's license issued by the State
Department of Licensing and Regulation as required by Act 299 of the Public
Acts of 1980, as amended (M.C.L.A. 339.101 et seq.), or failure to obtain or to
renew such license;
      (2)   Abandonment without legal excuse of any construction project or
operation engaged in or undertaken by the registrant or applicant;
      (3)   Diversion of funds or property received for the execution or
completion of a specific project or operation, or for a specified purpose
      EDITOR'S NOTE: BECAUSE OF THE 1994-C UPDATING AND REVISION OF THESE
CODIFIED ORDINANCES, THE NEXT NUMBERED PAGE IS PAGE 51.
               in the execution or completion of any construction project or
operation, and their application or use for any other construction project,
operation, obligation or purpose;
      (4)   Failure to account for or to remit any moneys coming into the
registrant's or applicant's possession, which moneys belong to others;
      (5)   Willful departure from or disregard of plans or specifications in
any material respect and prejudicial to another, without consent of the owner
or his or her duly authorized representative and without the consent of the
person entitled to have the particular construction project or operation
completed in accordance with such plans and specifications;
      (6)   Willful or deliberate disregard and violation of this Building and
Housing Code, other ordinances or regulations of the City or the building laws
of the State;
      (7)   Misrepresentation of a material fact by an applicant in obtaining a
registration certificate;
      (8)   Making any substantial misrepresentation or making any false
promise of a character likely to influence, persuade or induce;
      (9)   Advertising in any manner whatsoever that the residential builder
or residential maintenance and/or alteration contractor is registered under
this chapter;
      (10)   Changing business location without notification to the Building
Department within thirty days from the date of the change; or
      (11)   Any conduct, whether of the same or of a different character than
specified in this section, which conduct constitutes dishonesty or unfair
dealings.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.090)
1430.09 COMPLAINTS TO COMMISSION; TIME LIMITS.
   The Builders Registration Commission may consider only those complaints
which are presented to it in writing and which are made within one year after
the completion, occupancy or purchase of a residential structure. However,
complaints presented by the proper authorities charged with the enforcement of
City ordinances, codes and regulations governing construction of residential
structures shall be considered by the Commission only if made by written
complaint within sixty days after the completion, occupancy or purchase of the
structure.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.100)
1430.10 HEARINGS.
   The Builders Registration Commission, before refusing to issue or renew, or
before suspending or revoking, a registration certificate, and at least ten
days prior to the date set for a hearing, shall notify, in writing, the
applicant or registrant of any change made, and shall furnish the applicant or
registrant an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel in reference
thereto. Such written notice shall be served personally to the applicant or
registrant or by mailing the same by certified mail to the last known business
address of the applicant or registrant. The hearing shall be at such time and
place as the Commission prescribes. The Commission shall bring before it and
take the testimony of any person in the same manner as in judicial proceedings
in the civil courts. If the Commission finds that the applicant or registrant
is guilty of violation of this chapter, the Commission shall, as the case may
be, refuse to issue or renew the registration certificate of the applicant or
registrant, or suspend or revoke the same for such period of time as shall be
determined by the Commission.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.110)
1430.11 APPEALS TO COUNCIL.
   Any person whose registration certificate is suspended or revoked, or any
person whose application for issuance or renewal of a registration certificate
is refused, may appeal to Council, provided that a written request therefor is
filed with the City Clerk within ten days following the refusal, suspension or
revocation by the Builders Registration Commission. Council shall grant a
hearing on such appeal and may affirm or reverse any action of the Commission.
The decision of Council shall be final.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.120)
1430.12 ENFORCEMENT; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Builders Registration Commission shall administer and provide for the
enforcement of this chapter. The Commission is expressly vested with the power
and authority to make and enforce any and all rules and regulations not
inconsistent with this chapter. Copies of all such rules and regulations shall
be on file in the Building Department and shall be available to all persons for
inspection and review.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.12.130)
1430.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
1430.99 was repealed by Res. 04-76, passed March 1, 2004.)

CHAPTER 1440
Alarm Systems
1440.01   Definitions.
1440.02   Installation; State license required.
1440.03   Multiple occupancy buildings; separate alarms required.
1440.04   Equipment standards; inspections.
1440.05   False alarms; fees.
1440.99   Penalty. (Repealed)
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Police Department - see CHTR.
Ch. XV Secs. 4 et seq.; ADM. Ch.
235
   Fire Department - see CHTR.
Ch. XV Secs. 4 et seq.; ADM. Ch.
236
   Theft - see GEN. OFF.
662.01
   False alarms - see GEN. OFF.
666.03
   Fire alarms - see F.P.
Ch. 1622
1440.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Alarm system" means an assembly of equipment and devices arranged to
signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention.
   (b)   "False alarm" means the activation of an alarm system through
mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the
owner or lessee of the alarm system or of his or her employee or agent. "False
alarm" does not include an alarm caused by a hurricane, tornado, earthquake or
other violent condition beyond the control of the owner or lessee of an alarm
system or of his or her employee or agent.
(Res. 89-82. Passed 2-21-89.)
1440.02 INSTALLATION; STATE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate, conduct or engage in the business of installing an
alarm system without first being licensed by the State and meeting State
certification requirements for the type of alarm equipment being installed.
(Res. 89-82. Passed 2-21-89.)
1440.03 MULTIPLE OCCUPANCY BUILDINGS; SEPARATE ALARMS REQUIRED.
   No alarm shall cover more than one business place and/or residence, meaning
that buildings with more than one business must have a separate alarm for each
business located therein, provided each business has a separate entrance. No
single alarm shall cover a grouping of houses, apartments or condominiums which
have separate entrances to each living quarters. However, in case of fire
alarms (i.e. heat detector, smoke detector, sprinkler system supervision) or
any combination of systems in multiple occupancy buildings, an annunciation
panel shall be installed in an area which is readily accessible to the Fire
Department. The annunciation panel shall indicate in which occupancy or section
of the building the system was activated.
(Res. 89-82. Passed 2-21-89.)
1440.04 EQUIPMENT STANDARDS; INSPECTIONS.
   No alarm system shall be installed in the City unless the quality of the
equipment is Underwriters Laboratory approved or similarly comparable to
equipment generally accepted to be of good quality and performance in the alarm
industry. The installation of the alarm system and the equipment shall be
subject to inspection and approval of the Building Department once the system
is installed.
(Res. 89-82. Passed 2-21-89.)
1440.05 FALSE ALARMS; FEES.
   To ensure that all alarm equipment is properly maintained in good operating
order and to minimize the cost to the City for false alarms, the owner or
lessee of an alarm system will be assessed the following sums to defray the
cost of response time in a false alarm occurrence:
   (a)   For a first false alarm in a twelve-month period, no fees shall be
assessed.
   (b)   For a second false alarm in a twelve-month period, no fees shall be
assessed.
   (c)   For a third false alarm in a twelve-month period, the sum of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) will be assessed against the owner/lessor of an alarm
system.
   (d)   All false alarms subsequent to the third false alarm within a twelve-
month period will be assessed at the rate of fifty dollars ($50.00) each.
(Res. 89-82. Passed 2-21-89.)
1440.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
1440.99 was repealed by Res. 04-76, passed March 1, 2004.)
CHAPTER 1444

1444.01 DANGEROUS BUILDING DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "dangerous building" means any building or
structure which has any of the following defects or is in any of the following
conditions:
   (a)   Whenever any door, aisle, passageway, stairway or other means of exit
does not conform to the approved Fire Code of the City or State;
   (b)   Whenever any portion has been damaged by fire, wind, flood or other
cause in such a manner that the structural strength or stability is appreciably
less than it was before such catastrophe and is less than the minimum
requirements of the State Construction Code for a new building or similar
structure, purpose or location;
   (c)   Whenever any portion, member or appurtenance is likely to fall, become
detached or dislodged or collapse and thereby injure persons or damage
property;
   (d)   Whenever any portion has settled to such an extent that walls or other
structural portions have materially less resistance to wind than is required in
the case of new construction by the State Construction Code;
   (e)   Whenever the building or structure, or any part thereof, because of
dilapidation, deterioration, decay or faulty construction, or because of the
removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the purpose of
supporting such building or portion thereof, or for another reason, is likely
to partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or
underpinning is likely to fall or give way;
   (f)   Whenever for any reason the building or structure, or any portion
thereof, is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is used;
   (g)   Whenever the building or structure has been so damaged by fire, wind
or flood or has become so dilapidated or deteriorated as to become an
attractive nuisance to children who might play therein to their danger, or as
to afford a harbor for vagrants, criminals or immoral persons, or as to enable
persons to resort thereto for the purpose of committing a nuisance or unlawful
or immoral act;
   (h)   Whenever a building or structure used or intended to be used for
dwelling purposes, because of dilapidation, decay, damage, faulty construction
or arrangement or otherwise, is unsanitary or unfit for human habitation or is
in a condition that is likely to cause sickness or disease when so determined
by the Health Officer, or is likely to work injury on the health, safety or
general welfare of those living within;
   (i)   Whenever any building becomes vacant, dilapidated and open at doors or
windows, leaving the interior of the building exposed to the elements or
accessible to entrance by trespassers;
   (j)   Whenever any building or structure has light, air or sanitation
facilities which are inadequate to protect the health, morals, safety or
general welfare of persons who may live therein; or
   (k)   Whenever any building or structure has improperly distributed loads
upon the floors or in which the same are overloaded or which have insufficient
strength to be reasonably safe for the purposes for which the building or
structure is or is likely to be used.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.010)
1444.02 DECLARATION OF NUISANCE; ABATEMENT.
   No person shall maintain any structure which is unsafe or a menace to the
health, morals or safety of the public.
   The Superintendent of the Building Department may abate any public nuisance
if the public safety or health requires immediate action, without a preliminary
order of Council. The cost of abating such nuisance may be charged against the
premises and the owner thereof as a special assessment in accordance with
Chapter IX, Section 44, of the City Charter.
(1979 Code Sec. 8.20.020)
1444.03 PROHIBITIONS.
   No person shall keep or maintain any building, structure or dwelling, or
part thereof, which is a dangerous building.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.020)
1444.04 NOTICE OF DANGEROUS OR UNSAFE CONDITIONS; AFFIDAVIT.
   (a)   Issuance. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, when
the whole or any part of any building or structure is found to be in a
dangerous or unsafe condition, the Superintendent of the Building Department
shall issue a notice, in writing, of the dangerous and unsafe condition to each
owner of or party in interest in the alleged dangerous building in whose name
the property appears on the last local tax assessment records.
   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any premises who has received a notice
or upon whom a notice has been served to sell, transfer, mortgage, lease or
otherwise dispose of to another until the provisions of the notice have been
complied with, or until such owner shall first furnish the grantee, transferee,
mortgagee or lessee a true copy of any compliance order or notice issued by the
Superintendent of Building and shall furnish to the Superintendent of Building
a signed and notarized statement from the grantee, transferee, mortgagee or
lessee, acknowledging the receipt of such compliance order or notice and fully
accepting the responsibility without condition for making the corrections or
repairs required by such compliance order or notice.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.030; Res. 2016-232A. Passed 8-15-16. Eff. 8-24-16.)
   (b)   Contents; Hearings. The notice shall specify the time and place of a
hearing on the condition of the building or structure, at which time and place
the person to whom the notice is directed shall have the opportunity to show
cause why the building or structure should not be ordered to be demolished or
otherwise made safe.
   (c)   Service; Filing.
      (1)   Such notice shall be in writing and shall be served upon the person
to whom it is directed personally or by certified mail, return receipt
requested, addressed to each owner or party in interest at the address shown on
the tax records, at least ten days before the date of the hearing described in
the notice. If any person to whom a notice is directed is not personally
served, in addition to mailing the notice, a copy thereof shall be posted upon
a conspicuous part of the building or structure.
      (2)   The Superintendent shall file a copy of the notice of the dangerous
and unsafe condition of any building or structure with the Hearing Board on
Dangerous Buildings and Code Appeals.
      (3)   At the same time that the owner is notified of the hearing, the
Superintendent of the Building Department shall request the city attorney to
file a copy of the notice and order with the register of deeds office of the
county.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.050; Res. 2016-232A. Passed 8-15-16. Eff. 8-24-16.)
1444.05 HEARING BOARD ON DANGEROUS BUILDINGS AND CODE APPEALS.
   (a)   Appointments; Composition; Terms of Office. A Hearing Board on
Dangerous Buildings and Code Appeals shall be appointed for the purpose of
conducting hearings required by this chapter. The Board shall consist of five
members who shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to approval of Council,
and who shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and Council. Each member of
the Board shall be appointed for a three-year term. However, the original
members shall be appointed for one, two and three-year terms respectively. Of
the two additional members appointed pursuant to Resolution 87-431, passed
August 3, 1987, one shall be appointed for an original term of two years and
the other for three years.
   (b)   Powers and Duties. The Board, in addition to all its powers and duties
set forth in this chapter, shall act and serve as the Code Appeals Board.
   (c)   Hearings; Vote. The Board shall hold meetings at a minimum on a
quarterly basis, and if necessary on an as needed basis. Three members of the
Board must be present in order to conduct hearings or to hear appeals. A
majority vote of the five members of the Board constitutes a decision of the
Board.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.060; Res. 87-431. Passed 8-3-87; Res. 2016-232A. Passed
8-15-16, Eff. 8-24-16.)
1444.06 HEARINGS; DECISIONS.
   The Hearing Board on Dangerous Buildings and Code Appeals shall take the
testimony of the Superintendent of the Building Department, the owner of the
dangerous building and any interested party. The Board shall render its
decision, either closing the proceedings or ordering the building to be
demolished or otherwise made safe.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.070)
1444.07 ORDERS TO DEMOLISH OR MAKE SAFE.
   If it is determined by the Hearing Board on Dangerous Buildings and Code
Appeals that a building or structure should be demolished or otherwise made
safe, it shall so order, fixing a time not to exceed sixty days from the date
of the order for compliance therewith.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.080; Res. 2016-232A. Passed 8-15-16, Eff. 8-24-16.)
1444.08 NONCOMPLIANCE WITH NOTICE; REMEDY OF CITY.
   (a)   If an owner, agent or party in interest fails to appear or neglects or
refuses to comply with the order provided for in Section
1444.07, the Hearing Board on Dangerous Buildings and Code Appeals shall file a
report of its findings and a copy of its order with Council and request that
the necessary action be taken to demolish or otherwise make safe the building
or structure. A copy of the findings and order of the Board shall be served on
each owner or party in interest in the manner prescribed in this chapter.
   (b)   Council shall, upon receipt of the order and findings of the Board,
fix a date for a hearing to review the findings and order of the Board, and
shall give notice to each owner or party in interest in the manner prescribed
in this chapter of the time and place of the hearing. At the hearing, each
owner or party in interest shall be given the opportunity to show cause why the
building should not be demolished or otherwise made safe. Council shall either
approve, disapprove or modify the order for the demolition or making safe of
the building or structure and shall direct the Superintendent of Public Works
to comply with the order as approved or modified forthwith after twenty days
after the hearing.
   (c)   A decision from the city council modifying a demolition order to allow
repair or alteration to the building will require that the building's owner,
occupant, or lien holder complete all of the following
      (1)   Within 14 days of the city council's decision, post a cash or
surety bond with the city treasurer's office in an amount equal to the
Superintendent of Building's estimate of the cost to demolish the building;
      (2)   Within 14 days of the city council's decision, apply with the
building department for all permits necessary for the repairs to the building
and pay all permit fees;
      (3)   Obtain a certificate of occupancy from the building department
within six months from the date that the permits are issued, or within any
extensions of time that the building department may grant not to exceed an
additional six months. No extension shall be granted if no work had not begun
during the initial six month period.
      (4)   If the property owner and/or permit holders fail to comply with the
provisions of subsection (3) of this section in the time required therein, the
city shall retain all cash deposits to apply to the cost of demolition, the
excess amount, if any, to be returned to the owner.
      (5)   If the costs of demolition exceed the amount of any cash
deposition, the city will be permitted to exercise all other procedures for
collection of such costs permitted in this Code or state law.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.100; Res. 2016-232A. Passed 8-15-16, Eff. 8-24-16.)
1444.09 COSTS OF DEMOLITION OR MAKING SAFE; LIENS.
   The cost of demolition or making safe of a building shall be a lien against
the real property and shall be reported to the City Assessor. The City Assessor
shall assess the cost against the property on which the building or structure
is located in accordance with these Codified Ordinances and the City Charter.
   Each owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears upon the
last local tax assessment records shall be notified of the amount of such cost
by first class mail at the address shown on the records. If such amount is not
paid within thirty days after mailing, by the City Assessor, of the notice of
the amount thereof, the City Assessor shall add the same to the next tax roll
of the City. The same shall be collected in the same manner in all respects as
provided by law for the collection of taxes by the City.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.110)
   The remedy provided for herein shall be in addition to the penalty provided
in Section
1444.99.
1444.10 BUILDING CONTENTS; REMOVAL; STORAGE; DISPOSITION.
   If Council orders that a building be demolished, the Superintendent of
Public Works shall determine the date for demolition and shall then notify each
owner or party in interest thereof in the manner set forth in this chapter.
Such notice shall request that the owner or party in interest remove any
contents of the building which are of value to him or her.
   If, on the date set for demolition, the contents remain in the building
which, in the opinion of the Superintendent, are of more than nominal value,
the Superintendent shall cause such contents to be removed from the building
and stored for not more than ninety days. The owner or party in interest shall
be notified that during the period of storage the contents may be claimed upon
payment of a reasonable storage fee. Upon expiration of the storage period, the
contents shall be considered to be abandoned and may be disposed of by the
usual method of disposal of abandoned property. The demolition charges to the
owner or party in interest shall then be reduced by any amount the City
receives for the sale of the abandoned property, which amount is in excess of
the City's expenses for removal and storage of the same.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.120)
1444.11 APPEALS.
   Any owner or party in interest of a dangerous building or structure who is
aggrieved by any final decision or order of Council may appeal the decision or
order to the Circuit Court within twenty days from the date of the decision.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.130)
1444.12 EMERGENCIES.
   Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the Building Department from
summarily making safe any condition which, in the judgment of the
Superintendent of the Building Department, poses such an imminent hazard and
threat to personal safety that abatement must occur before the time limits
specified in this chapter.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.140)
1444.13 VIOLATIONS.
   No owner or party in interest in any dangerous building or structure shall
fail to comply with any final decision or order of Council.
(1979 Code Sec. 16.16.150)
1444.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
1444.99 was repealed by Res. 04-76, passed March 1, 2004.)
CHAPTER 1445
Emergency Abatement
1445.01   Emergency abatement.
1445.02   Cost of abatement; liens.
1445.01 EMERGENCY ABATEMENT.
   No person shall maintain any structure, or parcel of land improved or
unimproved, or associated appurtenances which are unsafe or a menace to the
health, safety and welfare of the public. The Superintendent of the Building
Department may abate any emergency situation if the public safety or health
requires immediate action, without a preliminary order of Council.
(Res. 07-295A, Passed 8-27-07.)
1445.02 COST OF ABATEMENT; LIENS.
   The cost of abatement may be charged against the premises and the owner
thereof as a special assessment. Such assessments shall be filed in the office
of the Finance Director as a lien against the lands so abated, and shall be
recorded in the public records of Wayne County, Michigan, to afford notice to
the public. Such assessment shall be a lien against the land against which the
same is made effective as of the date of levy by the City Assessor. Such lien
shall be prior, and prior in dignity, to all other liens against such property,
save and except a lien for taxes. Liens shall be payable on the date of levy,
and shall, from the date of delinquency thirty (30) days after the date of levy
bear interest at a rate of one half of one percent per month for each and every
month or fraction thereof that the same remains unpaid. The lien shall be
subject to foreclosure as provided by law.
(Res. 07-295A, Passed 8-27-07.)
CHAPTER 1448
Fences

1448.02   Permit required; application.

   CROSS REFERENCES

1294.29

1428.07
1448.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Fence" means a structure, barrier or partition of natural or
artificial materials erected to enclose a piece of land, divide a piece of land
into distinct portions, or separate two contiguous estates, or mark a boundary,
with the intention of preventing intrusion from without or straying from
within.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
   (b)   "Partition fence" means a fence located along the line dividing two
lots or parcels of land which are privately owned in the City, or a fence
located along the building setback line of the subdivision in which the
premises are located or along a line twenty feet from and parallel to the front
lot line of the premises, whichever is furthest from the front lot line.
(Res. 87-725. Passed 12-21-87.)
1448.02   PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   (a)   Application for Permit. No person shall erect or cause to be erected,
substantially rebuild or cause to be substantially rebuilt, a fence of any
nature, type or description within the City without first obtaining a permit
therefor from the Building Department issued in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter. Substantial rebuilding shall be reconstruction of more than
twenty feet of any fence within a twelve month period, a change in the height
of a fence, or a change of existing material Painting, cleaning, replacement of
like materials, or other general maintenance activities shall not be defined as
substantial rebuilding. All fences of any nature, type or description erected
or substantially rebuilt within the City shall comply with the regulations of
this chapter.
   A written application shall be filed setting forth the type of fence to be
erected, along with a diagram showing the location and legal description of the
premises on which the proposed fence is to be erected. The following minimum
information shall be included on the diagram submitted in support of a fence
permit application:
      (1)   Proposed fence location;
      (2)   Location of all existing structures within twenty-five feet of the
proposed fence;
      (3)   Location of all existing driveways within twenty-five feet of the
proposed fence;
      (4)   Location of all existing sidewalks within twenty-five feet of the
proposed fence; and
      (5)   Location of all existing fences within ten feet of the proposed
fence.
   The Building Superintendent may determine other additional information is
reasonably necessary to provide a complete review of the proposed fence. Such
additional information shall be provided by the applicant as may be required by
the Building Superintendent to assurance compliance with the regulations set
forth in this chapter and to assure the fence is constructed with sound
materials.
   If a fence is proposed in conjunction with a development that requires site
plan review, then the fence shall be shown on the site plan which shall be
reviewed in accordance with normal site plan review procedures. No additional
permit is required when a fence is approved ads part of a site plan.
   (b)   Application Review Fee. Each fence permit application shall be
accompanied by an application review fee to recover the reasonable costs for
review and fence permit issuance. The amount of the fee shall be fixed by
resolution of City Council and posted in the Building Department. If the fence
is constructed before an application for a fence permit is obtained, the fee
shall be increased to an amount equal to twice the fee that is required if the
application and fee were obtained prior to construction of the fence.
   (c)   Survey Required. In the event lot lines for the subject property
cannot be located to the satisfaction of the Building Superintendent, the
Superintendent may require the applicant to establish lot lines on the property
through placement of permanent stakes located by a licensed surveyor. Lot lines
must be located before a fence permit is issued. The Building Superintendent
may withhold issuance of a fence permit until the lot lines are located and
permanent stakes are placed by a licensed surveyor.
   (d)   Administrative Rules. The Building Superintendent may establish
reasonable rules and procedures, consistent with the intentions of this
chapter, which may be necessary to provide for the proper administration of
this chapter.
   (e)   Application Review and Fence Permit Issuance by the Building
Superintendent. The Building Superintendent shall review a fence permit
application and supporting data with respect to the standards set forth in this
chapter, other Codified Ordinances, and administrative rules which may be
established to provide for proper administration of this chapter. The Building
Superintendent shall grant a fence permit to construct a proposed fence upon
finding that the proposed fence fully complies with all applicable regulations.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
 1448.03   FENCES IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS.
   In those areas of the City zoned residential:
   (a)   Fences in Rear and Side Yards. No fence shall hereafter be erected
within any rear yard or side yard to a height in excess of six feet four inches
above the grade of the premises, or closer to the front lot line of such
premises than five feet behind the front building line of the principal
structure. Fences within a rear yard or side yard composed of deciduous or
evergreen shrubs may exceed the maximum height limit. Fences within a rear yard
or side yard may be sight-obscuring and of opaque materials intended to screen
a yard from view, having such qualities as to constitute a visual barrier.
   (b)   Fences in Front Yards. No fence shall hereafter be erected to a height
in excess of four feet above the grade of the premises at any point forward of
five feet behind the front building line of a principal structure to the front
setback line of the lot, or to a height in excess of three feet above the grade
of the premises from the front setback line to a point one foot from the public
sidewalk in any front yard. No fence shall hereafter be erected closer than one
foot from a public sidewalk, and any such fence permitted beyond the front
setback line must be non-sight obscuring and of an ornamental or decorative
design (e.g., picket fences, split rail fences, hedgerows). Decorative or
ornamental fences constructed under this section shall not be intended to
enclose or be capable of enclosing animals or human beings.
   (c)   Fences Surrounding Pools. A fence is required in every instance and
for each property upon which a pool, pond or fountain, any of which is capable
of holding twenty-four inches in depth or more of water, is located, regardless
of whether such pool, pond or fountain is permanent, portable or ornamental. In
all such cases, the gate servicing the fenced area shall be of the self-locking
type and shall be capable of being locked when the owner of the property upon
which the pool, pond or fountain is located is not on the premises and when
more than twenty-four inches in depth of water is in the pool, pond or
fountain.
   (d)   Fence Materials. Fences shall be of wood, not less than three-fourths
of an inch in thickness, of a chain-link type or of aluminum wire with strands
not less than twelve gauge, of wrought iron, of a composite plastic material,
of any other artificial material or combination of materials commonly used in
fence construction that are durable and suitable for exterior use, or of
deciduous and evergreen shrubs.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.04   FENCES IN BUSINESS OR INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS.
   In those areas zoned for business or industrial uses, no fence shall
hereafter be erected to a height in excess of six feet four inches above the
grade of the premises, or closer to the front lot line of such premises than
the front setback line of the principal structure. The owners or operators of
junk yards or salvage yards may erect a fence not in excess of ten feet above
the grade of the premises only after the approval of the Superintendent of the
Building Department.
   Signs advertising the availability of services or products shall not be
attached to any fence. The only sign that may be attached to a fence shall
indicate the name of the individual or company that constructed the fence and
that sign shall not exceed one square foot in area.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.05 CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS.
   The use of stone, brick, block, concrete, masonry or similar materials is
not prohibited in either a residential or commercial zone, provided that the
construction is attached to and part of the principal building located on the
premises, and provided, further, that the construction is in accordance with
all requirements of the Building Code of the City as to footings, quality, etc.
(Res. 87-725. Passed 12-21-87.)
1448.06 BARBED WIRE.
   No barbed wire shall be used in connection with the erection or maintenance
of any fence permitted under this chapter. However, on those portions of fences
enclosing industrial property and not fronting on Fort Street, Dix Highway,
Outer Drive, Southfield Road or John A. Papalas Drive, barbed wire strands may
be attached to arms or brackets affixed to a permitted fence and directed at an
inward angle over the private property at a height of not less than six feet
and not more than seven and one-half feet from the ground. Fences which carry
electric current or contain razor wire, concertina wire, or any other material
installed for the purpose of causing injury or harm shall be prohibited.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.07 EXCEPTIONS TO CHAPTER.
   (a)   Public Property. This chapter shall not apply to or regulate the
construction of fences on public property.
   (b)   Existing Fences. Fences existing prior to the adoption of this chapter
(Resolution 87-725, passed December 21, 1987), which fences do not fully comply
with this chapter, may continue unabated, provided they do not fall within the
categories listed in Section
1448.10.
   (c)   Other Provisions. This chapter shall not apply where a specific fence
requirement is contained elsewhere in these Codified Ordinances.
(Res. 87-725. Passed 12-21-87.)
   (d)   Construction Site Barriers. A temporary fence erected as a
construction site barrier to protect a construction site from vandalism and
unauthorized entry shall not require a fence permit unless the barrier will be
in place for more than one year.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.08 MAINTENANCE.
   All fences shall be maintained in a structurally sound condition, plumb,
true and in a safe and slightly manner. Rotten or broken components shall be
replaced, repaired, or removed. As required, surfaces shall be painted,
stained, or otherwise treated with materials to protect and preserve the fence
and provide an attractive finish. Wooden fences shall be properly surface-
coated with paint or stain, or constructed of pressure-treated lumber which
treatment has not deteriorated.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.09 REPAIRS.
   The Superintendent of the Building Department or his or her authorized
representative may order the repair of any fence that is basically sound, but
that contains component parts that are rusted, rotted, broken or otherwise
structurally deficient.
(Res. 87-725. Passed 12-21-87.)
   Failure to comply with written notice from the Building Superintendent
ordering completion of such repairs shall be deemed a violation of this
chapter.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.10   REMOVALS.
   The Superintendent of the Building Department or his or her authorized
representative shall order the removal of any fence which is unsafe or
dilapidated. The Superintendent may order the removal of any fence erected
after the adoption of this chapter, which fence does not fully comply with this
chapter.
(Res. 87-725. Passed 12-21-87.)
1448.11 CONSTRUCTION.
   All fences shall be independently installed and shall be self-supporting.
Fence posts shall be sunk into the ground to a depth of at least three feet,
with all posts encased in concrete below ground surface. Where a fence is
installed parallel to an existing fence, such fence shall not be attached to
the existing fence. Posts and supports, stringers, rails, etc., shall be on the
property side of the owner installing the fence (i.e. the finished side must
face outward) with the following exceptions:
   (a)   When a fence is approved for construction under a joint permit as
provided for herein this chapter, the joint permit holders shall determine the
preferred orientation of the more finished side of the fence along the common
property line(s) of the joint permit holders.
   (b)   An owner of abutting property may waive the right for the more
finished side of a fence to face his or her abutting property. Such waiver of
right must be in the form of a written consent statement, signed by the owner
of the property where the fence would face under the normal requirements of
this chapter. The written consent statement shall be attached to the fence
permit application and maintained with the fence permit records by the Building
Department.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.12   LOCATION.
   (a)   Private Property. Any fence shall be located entirely on the private
property of the person erecting it; no fence shall be erected on any easement,
alley, street, sidewalk, right-of-way, or other public property without the
express consent of City Council. There shall be a maximum of one fence per
property line for each property owner.
   (b)   Adjoining Properties and Fences. Adjoining property owners may jointly
apply for a fence permit, in which case the Building Superintendent may permit
it to be constructed on their common property line. A fence shall not be
attached to or touch a fence located on another lot without the express written
agreement of the owners of both fences.
   When a fence is erected parallel to an existing fence, no more than three
inches is permitted between such fences, and the maintenance of the area
between the fences shall be the responsibility of the property owner erecting
the newer fence. Fence panels may be raised four inches above grade to allow
for such maintenance.
   In every case, fences must be constructed with adequate posts and other
supports so that each fence is capable of maintaining an upright position and
the location described in the original fence permit application.
   (c)   Front Lot Lines and Corner Lots. Fences located along the side lot
line abutting a street on a corner lot, and fences along any front lot line,
shall be located no closer than one foot to the edge of the sidewalk or any
driveway, or one foot to the lot line if there is no adjacent sidewalk.
   (d)   Visibility. Any fence erected within ten feet of the intersection of a
driveway and a right-of-way shall permit a motorist unobstructed view of the
right-of-way when exiting the driveway. The sidewalk shall be visible for a
distance of ten feet on both sides of the driveway. Visibility shall be judged
three feet above the sidewalk from the garage doorjambs or ten feet from the
sidewalk along the driveway's edge, whichever is closer, whether or not the
fence is on the same lot as the driveway.
   (e)   Pedestrian Safety. If a fence is used on a corner lot to deter
pedestrians from walking through a private front yard area, the fence must be
visible so as not to present a safety hazard at night or during other times of
low visibility. Thin strands of wire, cable or cord shall not be permitted to
be attached to standing poles to form such fences.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.13 OBSTRUCTION OF PROPERTY.
   No fence shall be erected where it would prevent or unreasonably obstruct
the use of adjacent property, nor shall a fence be erected where it would
obstruct or prevent the continued safe use of an existing driveway or other
means of access to adjacent property. In enforcing this provision, the Building
Superintendent may require a fence to be set back greater than otherwise
required herein this chapter from a driveway or property line in order to
provide for the safe passage of pedestrians, bicyclists or vehicular traffic,
or other safety related concerns.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.14 APPEALS.
   An application for an appeal under this chapter shall be in writing and
shall be heard before the Zoning Board of Appeals.
(Res. 87-725. Passed 12-21-87.)
   The Zoning Board of Appeals shall review the appeal in accordance with the
standards and procedures for variances set forth in
Chapter 1264, Zoning Board of Appeals, of the City of Lincoln Park's Planning
and Zoning Code.
(Res. 01-520A. Passed 8-13-01.)
1448.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
1448.99 was repealed by Res. 04-76, passed March 1, 2004.)
CHAPTER 1450
Flood Damage Prevention
